We went to Xochitl with a living social voucher that provided us a choice of 4 courses each. i was pretty disappoint to find out soon after we arrived that our guacamole would not be made tableside like it is in the rest of the restaurant. That was a major disappointment because that is definitely a draw to any restaurant. We did get to customize our guac which is really a neat thing to do, especially with the tons of options they offered. Im a purist so we went simply with onions, tomato, cilantro, jalapeno and cotija cheese. Decent guac, but nothing really memorable.

Our drinks werent really very good either. My margarita was pretty flavorless. My fiances drink was ok, but again nothing worth noting.

Next course offered us a choice of huarache de hongos, ahi tuna ceviche or a salad. We went with the huarache de hongos and the ahi tuna salad, but by the looks of the plates, it looked like we got the salads on top of both of them. The huarache de honogos was a mushroom flatbread topped with seared wild mushrooms, artichoke hearts, and manchego and cotija cheese. what they didnt tell us in the description was that there was a mini salad on top of flatbread that covered the entire thing so you couldnt see anything underneath of it. It was far too much, and it really took flavor away from the flatbread. If I wanted to eat a salad, I would have ordered a salad. I really couldnt believe they did the same exact thing with the ceviche. The ceviche itself really wasnt very good, as it tasted more like tuna in tomato sauce with little no no heat and terrible texture, so manye that is why they layered the salad on top. It had no business being there, especially in that amount.

Luckily the mains faired a bit better. I ordered the shrimp chile nogada, why it wasnt all in spanish is beyond me, but it was fairly tasty. I love stuffed poblano peppers in all forms, and this was pretty good, even though the shrimp was kind of lost. If you had told me it was just filled with cheese, I never would have known the difference. My fiances camarones con caldo wasnt nearly as good. The shrimp were pretty good, but the sauce was very sweet and really didnt pack enough flavor. The avocado salad was nice.

Dessert was the best part of the meal for us. WHile we dont usually like tres leches cakes, this particular version of a chocolate tres leches cake was actually very good. It was creamy and rich and delicious. The vanilla flan was however the star. It was cheesy and bursting with vanilla flavor. It had a really nice caramel sauce served with it too. 

I really wish I could have tried this place when Michael Solomonov still owned it. I can imagine how exponentially better it would have been. Ill stick to my other Mexican favorites. This one missed the mark for me.

Stopped into to Xochitl yesterday evening with my boyfriend and our two friends. We had a reservation for 8, but it didn't look like it was needed as there was ample space to accommodate a party of 4.

The decor is beautiful, very cozy, intimate, and rustic. 

We ordered the guacamole for the table and it was great, I suggest customizing your guacamole to get the most of your experience! Be warned however, the portion is small so if you have a party of 2 or more I recommend ordering another serving!
Instead of ordering another guac, we wound up ordering the queso adding the chorizo, which was truly the knockout of the night. 

For our main course we all had tacos, I the shrimp, boyfriend and his friend the brisket, and his girlfriend the chicken. All of the tacos are good, but nothing to write home about!


Finally, the service was great. The server constantly made sure our water glasses were full, and paced out our meal flawlessly! 

Overall, I recommend swinging in here, and enjoying some queso!

Came here for drinks a few times during a long weekend in Philadelphia.  The bartenders are are really friendly and the margaritas are made well.  Try the margarita with jalapeños it is really refreshing and good.  The guacamole may have been the best I have had in a restaurant and I am from California were good guacamole is abundant.  The queso fondito was good as well.  If I was in Philly again, I would try to eat here for dinner.

I'm giving it four stars because I was a bit toasty when we went.  We waited in the bar for a table and drank a lot.  I had this terrible tomato-beer-something drink.  Whatever it was...don't get it.  The food was VERY creative and delicious.  Not your typical Mexican.  We shared a lot of the dishes and everything i ate was great.  There's a sampler plate that you'll definitely want to get because it has so many different items you'd never try.  Definitely a restaurant to return to.  Maybe i'll update it 5 stars.

This is a great place for Mexican! It has fresh ingredients and a cool fun atmosphere. I loved everything from my margarita to the desert. The hours are a little funny... make sure to have reservations. They have a funky little lounge down stairs that looks like an awesome place to chill for some drinks.

Decided to try out the place during Philly Restaurant Week (winter 2017). Ambience is very quaint and quiet. Dined on a Sunday evening and the place seemed very relaxed and dim.

Tried the Create your own guacamole, which was very delicious. There are several options to add to create a tasty starter before the main entree!

Second course tried the Spinach Ensalda--spinach, apples, cranberries, pepitas, cotija cheese, Serrano, and cilantro dressing! This was very flavorful and packed a little kick of spice. I normally don't try salads while dining, but this one definitely caught my attention and I'm glad it did!

Also had the Huarache de Hongos--homemade corn masa flatbread with sautéed mushrooms. Another flavor packed dish. Not big on mushrooms but these definitely excited my palate.

Third course I had the Shrimp Tacos---jumbo shrimp marinated citrus and herbs. My least favorite of the night. Just tasted as I was missing something, another ingredient perhaps, or it needed a crunchier tortilla. I don't know but the other dishes definitely made up for it!

Service was great and every employee we encountered was pleasant!

Would probably visit again for drinks and guacamole!

This was the first and last time we are going here.  Overall, one of the worse meals we've had in Philly.  Went here for dinner.  Service (at least the waitress we had) was below average.  Paid nearly 10 bucks for gourmet guacamole, which was not very good and did not seem fresh.  I had the Pollo Frito, which I thought was pretty good - very tender and moist.  My wife, however, had a different experience with her dish.  She had the short rib tamales - sounds good, right? - far from it.  It tastes like beef jerky and like it had been sitting out there for a week.  The tamale was like eating dry cardboard.  Needless to say, we did not stay for dessert.

I came with Emily for New Year's Eve half expecting to be told that it was $75 admission. They allowed us to sit at the bar and order a la carte.

Perfect start, nothing makes me more pleased than flexibility. When served with a side of ceviche, you've got a winning combination! It was a surprisingly generous portion - enough for us to share. I enjoyed the dish.

Next up - a jalepeno salmon dish served with pureed corn. Their salmon came stuffed with crab, which made the dish all the more hearty. The corn tasted tangy and truly smoothed out the hint of spice that the jalepenos brought to the plate.

We finished it up with a mousse dessert and it really did the trick for putting us in a great mood. We had more than enough to share and yet feel stuffed for under $60.

The bar and restaurant was very clean and well kept. Servers were friendly and very attentive; I definitely think it's no exaggeration to call the service we got top notch.

Excellent, select-your-own guacamole and good chips. Drinks were extremely strong which depending on your preference is either great or a little overwhelming. Good food, but smaller plates which encourage sharing. Not as much distinct flavors as some other mexican places I would prefer first.

Last night we had a very pleasant experience. The service was there when we wanted it. All dishes were excellent, as were the applications for the Kalamari and Guacamole. I had El Dorado, a crab-fish salmon with a very pleasant sauce and unique vegetation. We would definitely return again.

It was after 10PM by the time we arrived at Xochitl.  Upon entry, we waited for a couple minutes, but we didn't see the hostess.  I flagged down a waiter who was busily moving about with dishes bound for a table downstairs. He informed us that they didn't have a hostess at that hour, but would get us seated shortly.  And indeed he did.

We've been to Xochitl a couple times before.  We had previously returned because it had the best chicken torta in the city, but then that item fell off the menu, no where to be found.  The revamped menu was OK, but not good enough to go all the way out east just for it.  Since we were nearby that night and hungry, we dropped by to give it another chance.  I'm glad we did.

We had the make-your-own guac with Spanish onions, roasted tomatoes, cojito, truffle oil, and a pepper whose name I can't remember.  I thought this was so-so and was missing a little bit of something.  But, this wasn't the restaurant's fault since it was us who picked the ingredients.  Shame on us.

We split the Pollo Frito - a half chicken that was brined for 24 hours, steamed, fried, and drizzled with sweet chile sauce.  It was paired with corn bread and spinach in a chile cream.  The chicken was fried perfectly, with the sweet chile sauce serving as a good contrast to the spicier chile cream of the spinach.  Definitely a repeat to be had.

We also had the fish tacos - achiote lime marinated walu fish layered with mexican slaw and wrapped in house made tortillas.  I'm not normally a fan of fish tacos as the flavors are often more bland.  The flavors of these tacos weren't bland, but just more subtle.  Another repeat to be had.

The only big service miss was that our guac came out late because there was confusion in the kitchen regarding whether we already got it or not (we didn't). 

Overall, a nice comeback Xochitl.

Great authentic Mexican food, very clean , and nice ambiance- Not only was the food great- Justin our server went above and beyond to make sure we had an amazing first experience. He supplied us with not only great service but things to do in the area . Felt like we were at home. Definitely recommend if you are in the area.

The margaritas pack a wallop and are not very sweet - make sure you REALLY like tequila before you order.  We had, oh, 8:00 p.m. reservations and were seated promptly.  The food was fine...the guacamole was nothing special but the queso fundido was freaking amazing...my husband got the short ribs, I, the salmon.  Our friends got something we never would get so I completely forget but they seemed pleased.  I honestly could have done without my entree as could my husband and just gotten another order of queso fundido.  It was your typical "I'm trying to be really unique and interesting but really I've used too much sauce and spice for this to be that awesome" fare.  Pretty pricey...service was good.

I went to Xochitl with a group of 5 other friends for restaurant week. The atmosphere and service was very good, even if it took a while before we placed any orders. We ordered guacamole for the table that came in a heaping pile and was fresh and tasty. For appetizers, I got a dish that was essentially a small pizza that was topped with mushrooms and chicken. It was decent and filling, but very greasy. My friend was not pleased with her empanadas appetizer. For my entree, I got shrimp in a poblano pepper smothered in cheese. The taste of the cheese was overwhelming, and unfortunately the cheese wasn't anything special. My friends that got the short ribs were disappointed with the lack of flavor in their dishes too. We got a bottle of hot sauce, and it helped a lot. I'm not one to love spicy foods, but I need a little bit of flavor. My friend who got the steak and potatoes enjoyed her food (though what Mexican place serves steak and potatoes?)

I'd maybe come back for tacos & drinks, but I wouldn't bother with the high prices of restaurant week.

Do Not Eat at Xochitl.

My boyfriend and I were treated very nicely  by the manager when we first arrived since it was are first time in, but our waiter and the manager were incredibly inattentive for the rest of the time. The manager and waiter would check on other tables but not ours--even though they were continuously passing us. 

So, we ordered the "award-winning" guacamole and two different ceviches. The guacamole was disappointing and the ceviches were not fresh. I took a small spoonful of ceviche and was overwhelmed by a fishy taste, so I decided to send it back.

After flailing my arms for 15 minutes to get my waiter's attention, I asked if I could switch out the ceviche for something else. He took the ceviche away and informed me that I would have to pay the price for the new dish. I said that was fine and then said I needed time to decide on a new item, he never returned for the order until I had to flag him down again, and by that time I was unimpressed and fed up with the whole establishment that I just asked for the check so my boyfriend and I could leave. 

I ended up having to still pay for the one bite of bad ceviche that I had,the ceviche my boyfriend got and didn't like, the saddest guacamole I have ever eaten to date, and included tip even though I received poor service from the staff.

i thought the margaritas were great but the rest of the drinks were not my thing.  (nothing that tastes like cough syrup is ever going to be "my thing")  appetizers were wonderful (oh my guacamole) but they totally lost steam when it came to the entrees.  very adorable atmosphere.  i'd go back for drinks n snacks.

Wow, went here in a group of 4 and had a fantastic meal.  We ordered the El Sabor, which consists of tableside guac, 1 app pp, and 1 entree pp.  The guacamole is the best I've ever had.  I always thought I made a mean guac but mine is nowhere near this.

Among our apps we had the Queso Fundido, Chorizo y Papas, Tostadas de Ceviche, and the Huaraches.  All were excellent.  I think my fave was the chorizo y papas.

Our entrees were Costillas de Puerco, Pollo, Albondigas, and Salmon.  All were great.  

I casually mentioned to the waitress that my Albondigas was very spicy.  I was not complaining, I love it that way.  She thanked us for the heads up, then the manager comped us desserts and shots.  Amazing.

Great service, great food, great place.  Our server was Sara and she was very talented.  Her attentiveness and professionalism made the night that much better.

I went here for restaurant week. I took my date there and it was a nice atmosphere within the spot. 

The fish tacos were good. Just what I expected. The service was fine nothing over the top and nothing awful. My complaint was that it was getting cold and they had the door and the air on, we asked for them to fix either and they did not. Now no one likes to be uncomfortable while eating. That defiantly made me want to leave quicker. 

Other than that, the margaritas were delicious and so was the make your own guacamole. I would have preferred to sit in a booth since we made a reservation instead of a high table. I would have actually waited had I known I was going to sit with a draft on me. 

I would go back for happy hour. I think I can do without for an actual meal.

Fantastic experience there.  Some of the best drinks we've ever had, incredible food that is not cheap, but not not unreasonable for what it is.  What really stood out was the service, the manager was very hands on and the wait staff were very friendly and attentive.  Overall perfect experience there.

I go to this place once a week at least.  Their sangrita tequila chaser makes me crave tequila.  (something I usually don't even drink.)  It's a spicy sweet juicy little tomato juice cup of deliciousness.
Their chicken sandwich on the late night menu is my latest culinary love affair.  I dream about it at night.   The chicken is juicy thigh meat, they spread black beans on the soft fluffy bread, it comes with avocado and summer tomatoes and is accompanied by spicy hot peppers! mmmmmm.  
     You gotta go after 10 to get this though.  
      I love that they also have many veggie options as I am oft accompanied by an herbivore pal.  
The bar staff is fast, communicable and entertaining....
My glass never even gets close to being empty at this place, never am i left waiting, staring into outer space for another cocktail to wind up in my grasp....I am consistently amused and pampered and always leave feeling more super than when I arrived.

A whole group of us got rejected from Stella's next door and ended up here.  This place is more upscale than your average on the street mexican food.  The tequila was great.  The make your own guac was original and fun for a crowd.  We got a little of everything...the whole/half chicken was EXCELLENT- would love to get this again and again.  The tamales and fish tacos were just ok.  They have plenty of seating upstairs and downstairs and are great for crowds.  Decent food but nothing out of this world.

We went her Friday night, and we had an open table coupon.  It was really great.  The main entrees were a little spendy for our taste (mid to high 20's) but there was plenty else to choose from on the menu and it was all good and different.  We had the "build your own" guacamole and it was to die for.  I highly recommend getting the truffles in it.  Wow.  We also had tuna ceviche, tacos and a mushroom dish that was all so yummy we wanted to savor it.  The best part though, was a side dish of corn that my husband couldn't stop talking about.  The wait staff was really nice to.  We didn't have any drinks, so I can't speak to that, but we will certainly go back for the food.

Such a cute and cozy restaurant. If you go, you must order the guac and margaritas. They allow you to customize the guacamole to your liking and, if you can't decide between the many options, the servers offer will their pairing suggestions. So fresh and homemade tasting, I'm not even a guac fan and I practically licked the bowl clean! The margaritas were similarly delicious... a perfect pairing. As for the entrees, I wasn't completely impressed. I ordered the steak tacos and also tasted the short rib tamales. Nothing was wrong, just expected a little more for what they were charging. I will say that the Mexican corn was great. When I've had it in the past, it's been served on the cobb, which is extremely messy and difficult to eat. Xochitl serves it cut up and in a bowl so you don't have to worry about a cheesy mess all over your face. I had an enjoyable evening, but will probably return just for happy hour.

I can see what the restaurant is going for but it misses its mark by far! It is fairly small and the food flavors are not authentic Mexican. 
However, the drinks are delicious.

We came here for Restaurant week because they give you a fair amount of options and 3 courses + guacamole. It was good, the guacamole is customizable which is cool, although you have to pay for mix-ins after a certain point. The base guacamole they give you is only avocado, lime and evoo, so three is enough to get you red onions, cilantro and garlic to make it actual guac. 

For appetizer I had the Huarache de Hongos which was something like a cotija cheese and mushroom flatbread. It was definitely tasty, and really large compared to the empanadas. 

For my entree I got Camarones Con Caldo on recommendation by the waiter. It was tasty but not out of the ordinary. It was like 6 or 7 regular sized spicy shrimps. It said it came with "avocado salad" but it was really just cilantro salad with a few tiny pieces of avocado in it. It did come with fried plantains though, which will always get extra points for me. 

One of my friends got the salmon, which was good but also not out of the ordinary. The other got the flat iron steak which was probably the best (if you like steak) of the three. It was thicker than most flat iron steaks and cooked perfectly (asked for medium rare). 

We got the white sangria...which came with ice. It had tequila in it which kind of overpowered the wine, and when I said ice, they give you a LOT of ice so that by the time you've finished unless you're sucking it down really quickly it's pretty diluted. 

For dessert I had the flan, which I didn't really care for at all (and I love flan normally). The flavors were just off and kind of strange. The chocolate cake was nothing like our waiter described, but it was awesome I should have gotten that. And then the churros were freshly fried and came with a good sauce.

It was about 4:30 pm when we were heading to another restaurant down the street but forgot that they didn't open until 5. So we checked our options and saw that Xochitl was up the block. They too didn't serve dinner until 5, but was able to sit at bar order drinks and some chips, salsa and guacamole. 
The staff was very friendly. The deco was very true to Mexican design with tiles, heavy wood and lanterns. And the food was excellent. They're not large potions, so you didn't feel full when the plate was put in front of you., like in some restaurants was just enough....to have dessert. I had the mushroom tamale and for dessert the flan...OMG, the flan! Yeah, you gotta check this place out.

I guess this place is known for their drinks cause the food is downright repulsive. We ordered the guacamole which had no flavor and jalapenos with all the seeds in it, making it inedible. The next course was the appetizer which was a crab spread on a croustade. You physically cannot bite into the croustade it was so hard. The crab smelled so bad I could barely have it on the table. My entree was actually delicious, I had the stuffed chicken but the second I put the last bite in my mouth I ran straight to the bathroom which is tiny and next door to the kitchen and got so sick. My boyfriend also got sick about an hour later. He had the surf and turf which was a small filet mignon with all the sinews still in it and a lobster tail with no flavor. The menu said it came with haricot certs but they gave us three strips of green pepper thinking we wouldn't know the difference. Wish I knew better. Don't go to Philly for mexican food.
I dined here some time ago.  Food and drinks were great.  My entree was the spiciest thing I've ever had!  A true culinary adventure.  Great service and location.  Highly recommended.

Went to dinner here with a group of couples... Not a huge fan of the food, I expected better based on reviews, etc.  I wouldnt say it was terrible by any means I just think there are far better Mexican dining options out there... HOWEVER, I am a huge fan of their drink menu.  Very good spicy margaretas and spoke with the bar tender and he worked up some personal concoctions that were awesome too.  All in all, I have been back for drinks but not to dine.  Bar is not really a big happening scene but if you want a quiet night with some cool drink options, not a bad option.

If you are really into guac, this is the only place i've been to where you can literally order custom made guac with mix-ins like pomegranate, truffle oil, and cojita cheese. They also have great margaritas and fish tacos.

The guac was pretty darn good and it's great that they have it made to order with lots of different additions to choose from!  Lots of chips too, which is nice.

I went with a friend and we ordered the molcajete tacos.  Pretty good for the price and the selections of meats/veggies that were included.  Nothing to write home about, but it was yummy and I'd return!

The service was a bit lacking, which is never fun, but I'd try it on a different night perhaps!

Been to Xochitli twice. Uneven results.

First time was happy hour, just drinks and apps. The Margaritas are only $5.00 and they're honestly bomb-dot-com. Had the Guacamole and wish there was more.  

Second time, went for dinner -- not so great. First the waitress came around and asked us what we wanted. We had only even gone to get the well-advertised February Dinner and Cocktail Special. I guess they didn't get their memo: there were no specials offered. So, we settled for some regular menu items. After we ordered, she let us know that the meals would take a really long time to come out, so we'd probably want to order the Guacamole. This she said to every table. Having been underwhelmed by the serving size of the Guacamole on my previous visit, I declined. After 30 minutes, our entrees finally surfaced. They weren't bad, but they were nothing to write home about. And especially for the price, the portions left much to be desired. If it weren't for the Margaritas, you'd only see two stars in this review.  Honestly, if it you want Mexican food in Phili, go to Cantina.

Great place! Another spot I tried during restaurant week.  Guacamole made to order once you choose ingredients. Love that!  I tried the flatbread and shrimp entree. I filled up on the guacamole & chips and flatbread so, I couldn't enjoy the shrimp.  I will definitely be back. Oh, if you like tequila this is the spot to try a flight.

Came back after many years away. Happy to report service is still outstanding and food is even better than remembered. Can't say enough about the staff, we were checked in on more than once by the manager but not in a pushy way. In fact, they looked understaffed. But if the staff were stressed it wasn't passed on to the customers. Won't take me so long to come back the next time.
Delicious food,  Good margaritas and amazing appitizers. The place is quite small and the service can be a bit slow. Its a family style place. nice decor.  overall I would definitely recommend

"Meh. I've experienced better." Pretty much sums it up. 

We had a reservation for 8:30, but were not seated until about 40 minutes later. I understand that sometimes patrons refuse to leave, which is out of the restaurant's control, but that's something they should account for when booking reservations. Also, the hostess had kind of a nasty attitude when we inquired politely about our table after 30 minutes of waiting. She offered to send down the manager, who was apologetic and gave us complimentary margaritas and guacamole, so at least he was nice and the gesture was appreciated. One star for the nice manager who gave us free stuff. 

However, waiting 40 minutes for our table was only the beginning of a long night of waiting. Service was extremely slow and each course took forever to arrive. The waitress was pleasant enough, but didn't stop by to say something like, "I'm sorry for the wait, your food should be out shortly." The bussers did their job pretty well, though. 

The food itself was mediocre. The guacamole was decent, but not amazing. It was comparable to the guacamole you can buy at Trader Joe's, which is good but also costs a fraction of the price. I was excited to try the ceviche appetizer, but it was unimaginative and even tasted kind of sour (in a bad way) and funky, which is not good when it comes to raw fish. This made me sad because I love both mackerel and ceviche. The braised short rib entree was good; it was probably the only thing that impressed me (this is where the other star comes from). My dining companions were not thrilled with their scallop or pork dishes, though. The desserts were not even worth mentioning, but I will anyway. The churros were dry and hard and tasted like 3-month-old stale donut sticks sprinkled with cinnamon sugar. The tres leches was bland with a weird frosting and a "pear compote" which was more like a few pieces of canned Del Monte diced pears. Overall, it was an underwhelming experience with slow service, a hostess with an attitude problem, and average food.

Had reservations Friday for Zahav's and decided to stop at Xochitl for a drink on the way.  Ended up cancelling our reservations at Zahav.  Have been there and really loved it, but decided to try something new.  Xochitl, with their fresh squeezed lime margarita's, the awesome, but a little pricey, guacamole, the fantastic pork cheek tacos and the skirt steak were awesome.  Great experience and on the rotation for a return visit!!

I've frequented Xochil many times and have always had a positive experience.  I went there on a date for dinner and everything we had was top-notch.  I had the Aztec soup, delicious!  For appetizers we had the quesa fundido, also delicious.  For the entree I had the pork tenderloin with chipotle sauce, potatoes, and poblano peppers, amazing!  For drinks we had several of their margaritas.  A little salty, but very good.  

I've also gone here several times late night.  Between 10 pm and 12 on Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays, margaritas are only $5 (compared to the usual $10) and beers are only $2.  We often go here then go out to Olde City or somewhere in Society Hill.  Plus the lounge downstairs is very chill and a good place to go if you have a big group.  I highly recommend this place.

I was so hyped up to come here last night for dinner. It looked so beautiful inside and located on a quaint side of town.

My friend and I have been craving guacamole for a long time, so we wanted to see what the whole fuss was about. Now we know. It was really neat to watch the waiter make our guacamole in front of our eyes. We got the guacamole special which was the guacamole on the menu plus some extra ingredients, which for us were truffles and manchego cheese I think. Cilantro and some jalapeno are mashed into the guacamole; don't be afraid of the jalapeno, you won't feel the spiciness.

So this is one of those places where if you sit in the dining room, you won't be able to take advantage of the happy hour special. Lame. I'm not a tequila fan, and even after a drink here I'm still not a tequila fan.

We got the enfrijoladas to split between the two of us because we were determined to finish our guacamole and we were limited to veggie and fish options due to our dietary restrictions at the moment. They were alright. I expected seeing more, erm, exotic vegetables inside as opposed to seeing mixed vegetables which I can easily get from the freezer section of the supermarket.

And service. Really, now? I see you giving other customers better service, what the hell? Biscotti with the check, really? Well we never got one, thanks very much. We barely saw our waitress and when asking them for advice, I never got any.

Never want to go back. Really, a meal that looks like I could have microwaved it myself, happy hour limitations, and curt service. Awful. One star experience, another star salvaged for guacamole.

You let me down Xochitl. You so-cheet-ed me. Have a good life.

Jackie and I met her parents here last night for dinner.

Everyone got Margaritas except me, I ordered a jarito of the Milagro  Anejo tequila. I used to love it when they would give you a setup of Cucumber and Tomato cups which makes sipping tequila so much nicer, every once in a while if sitting at the bar the bartender will hook you up with them.

M & D got the soup which they get all the time when they go there.

I got the ribs which were really good and so did her mother.

Dad got the Brisket which he enjoyed and Jackie got the veal which she did not like too much as it had no taste. 

M& D ordered Flan for desert which they seem to order every time they go as well.   

Jackie got the churros given to her on the house for the veal.

Ordering a margarita should be about the tequila not the amount of ice in the glass as the first round of drinks when down so fast you couldn't tell if there was tequila in them so I suggested getting them straight up which everyone liked better.

Over all I still enjoy this place and will be back ...

Though my meal was very good, I'm evaluating Xochitl against restaurants in the league in which it wants to play. And it missed the mark on several notes. I won't write it off, but the inconsistency I experienced, even in a single visit has me feeling let down by the experience overall.

My boyfriend and I were looking for a new-to-us restaurant to try, and we ventured down to Headhouse Square where there were several choices we were considering. Xochitl seemed cozy & inviting, but that was ripped from us almost immediately, as the too-cool-for-school host greeted us with a sneer when we said we didn't have reservations. Dude, it was 9:00pm on a Saturday night, you had plenty of tables open--and we wouldn't have minded a wait. Lose the 'tude.

We were encouraged to try the tasting menu (note fyi: others on the site have mentioned a $35 price tag. Either costs have gone up, or Saturday's menu is different, but the tasting menu was $45): a 5-course selection including guacamole for the table, an appetizer, ceviche, main course, and dessert. IMO, it's an excellent value, but my response to the food shifted fairly drastically from course to course.

The guacamole had all the right elements, but fell somewhat flat. It needed a kick, and since it's prepared tableside, I wish our preparer had either stuck around, or checked back in with us to see if the seasoning needed adjusting. 

My appetizer was the Ensalada Xochitl. YUM! Avocado, papaya, watermelon and fennel salad with tequila vinaigrette... refreshing and absolutely delicious. Our server also brought out an amuse bouche: a single grilled scallop atop a slice of watermelon, also grilled. I expected the melon to be cold, and sweet. Grilling it brought out a sour taste, which wasn't a bad complement to the scallop; it was just a flavor that took me by surprise.

My ceviche was a trio served on tostadas: shrimp, octopus, and mackerel. The mackerel was very disappointing, but the other two were quite good. 

My main course was phenomenal--Pescado al Pastor: a black bass served with a plaintain pancake and a rice that was citrus scented, and delicious. The plaintain felt like kind of an afterthought; it neither added nor detracted from the dish. However, I was very pleased with this dish, if I came back for this and the salad, I might be looking at Xochitl as a 4-star joint.

Dessert. Yummy. Churros for the bf, served with two dipping sauces: mexican chocolate and cajeta, and a carmelized bananas dish with vanilla/walnut ice cream for me. This was a nice finish to the meal, although I was surprised I still had room at this point.

Aside from the food, there were other details that were inconsistent as they pertain to service, presentation, and atmosphere. Service was generally good, but for its level, I would expect a little more. Our server was very attentive, guiding us through the menu and making an earnest attempt to tell us about each dish she set before us. However, she was so soft-spoken, I couldn't hear a word. A few times we asked her to repeat herself; I even cupped my ear to try to give her a polite, but explicit cue that I couldn't hear, but to no avail. We gave up. The dishes were beautifully presented--every single one of them. But, the plates have a busy pattern that competes with its presentation. These are small details, but with such artistry in the food, why not just set it off on a simple canvas? The atmosphere is so nicely appointed and inviting... but the attitude of the host, who is responsible for initially setting the tone, was obnoxious. Xochitl also doesn't seem to be very decisive about how it wants its guests to dress: the club vibe from the lounge suggests one thing; the low key, intimate bar setting another; and the dim lighting of the dining room yet another. My date and I, as well as the majority of diners while we were there, were dressed casually.

I didn't check out the downstairs, but it sounded like a bustling lounge that would be fun to hang out in, and the bar area looks like a great spot to visit. I want to give this place another chance, but bottom line: I'm not sure I'll be rushing back so fast to do so.

I had the pleasure of dining at Xochitl which had an impressive bar and food menu! Like the other reviews, I recommend starting with the "build your own quacamole" and a fresh squeezed lime/ house made simple syrup margarita. For entrees, the pollo frito was the star of the evening -- delightful. The chicken was brined, steamed and fried so the final result wasn't the least bit greasy, yet crispy, and flavorful. The creamed spinach side dish was also amazing. We even placed another order for the pollo frito as we decided to bring it to a guest who had to cancel last minute.The staff is very friendly, attentive and knowledgeable about mexican cuisine. Last but not least, the ambiance is great. Overall, a wonderful dining experience!

I loved the mixed seafood in red sauce with rice.  Sweetheart's salmon stuffed with crabmeat was a disappointment (dry).  The guacamole made your way is a cute touch, and very fresh.  Margarita selection is delightful.  I had blood orange, which was delish.  The ambiance in this little restaurant "feels" Central American.  Very pleasant, not too loud.  Service was very quick and efficient.  I liked this place, but still seeking my favorite Mexican restaurant in Philly.....

My friends and I went here to celebrate, and celebrate we did. We did not however eat, so this review does not reflect on what they serve for food. It dwells simply on the drinks and the atmosphere.

Do: plan on dancing. We came mainly for their friday night dj from the ill vibe collective. It was great for salsa style dancing (mexican or peruvian style ;-)
Do Not: get margaritas? My margarita aficionado for the evening was not all that impressed.
Do: drink the tequila, with a chaser. I forget what it was called, but it was a spicy tomato juice. I swear with that stuff as the chaser I could have finished a whole bottle of tequila... not that I would.
Do Not: let the man get you down (or the crowd). The night I went there seemed to be two distinct crowds. One group was the dancing type (my friends and I were part of that group) and the other group was determined to stare and glower at us (they were jealous). If you want to dance, dance. If you want to chill and listen to the music, you can do that too, because the DJ was awesome.

This is a place I will be returning to.

We ate here tonight for restaurant week. It was a great dining experience! We started with the make your own guacamole, and added garlic, onion, tomato, habanero, and cotija cheese. It was nice and fresh with house made chips. For apps I got the chicken tortilla soup, which was delicious. My boyfriend got the molletes, which were also very good. For my main I got the chicken enchiladas and they were great. Really nice flavor and a good amount of spice. I didn't care for the rice that came with them, and I told the waiter who then comped one of our drinks. The service was great. My boyfriend had the steak and charizo tacos and he enjoyed them. For dessert we split the flan and tres leches cake and both were tasty. 
For drinks, we tried the xochitl marg, the spicy pepino marg, the prickly pear marg, and a drink with pineapple and cinnamon. They were all really good. Not strong alcohol wise though. 
We would definitely come back!

My wife and I are regulars here. We usually eat at the bar and the chief bartender Ian is outstanding. The guacamole is homemade with lots of variations. All of the food is fresh, hot and very very tasty. Pricing is reasonable atmosphere nice but does get noisy so if you're looking for a quiet intimate evening this is not the place. Other than that definitely a great experience.

First off, they can really work on their customer service. My mom, fiancée and I came here for dinner. It was around 530 on Friday so they still had happy hour going on. They said we couldn't order happy hour drinks at the table so I went up to the bar to order the drinks for my party. (Why they make this arbitrary rule, no one knows.) Anyway I order the 3 drinks at the bar and the manager comes up to me and tells me he will give me these drinks on happy hour but any other drinks will need to be ordered from the table where there isn't happy hour. Mind you the drinks come from the same bar. This obviously rubs me the wrong way to begin with. 

Next, my mom and I order tacos. They were mediocre. This is a Mexican restaurant so we order a side of salsa each for our  bland tacos. The waitress says nothing about an additional charge at this point or that she recommend we get one since the sizes are large. She brings out 2 pretty large containers of salsa which we only use a scoop of each. Once the bill comes out we realize she charged us $4 for salsa. We point out the $4 charge to our waitress who then says "you wanted it didn't you?" Since she couldn't handle the situation she brings her manager out (same guy as before). He proceeds to argue over this salsa surcharge.... Naming other restaurants that charge for salsa and chips. I'm in shock at this point. When he finally realizes that we ordered side salsa and she charged us for the menu price of 2 salsa and chip containers he starts to back away from his argument. 

Charging for salsa is one thing but not being transparent, nickel and dimming your customers and poor customer service with poor performing food is another.

There was a lot of amazing food at Xochitl.  I think it's sin is that I trusted them to lead me through a culinary experience... after all it was on their menu to try a five course meal.  But I am getting ahead of myself.

Wanted to try something new we hit the little strip near the Open Air Market in Old City. As is the norm when I visit there it was snowing. We showed up reservation-less at Xochitl and were "greeted" by an angry hipster who clearly didn't think we deserved to be there.  Ok - no reservation - but we were also the second to last table seated that night... and there were several open tables... including SEVERAL that would have been much nicer than the one we got... but I digress.

The menu looked good - if maybe lacking in description.  It was clear this was because the wait staff wanted to tell us about the preparations.  We ordered the 5 course deal - for me it was guacamole made at the table, A trio of tamales, a tuna ceviche, the Aztec skirt steak, and a dessert to be named later.

Now - I'll point out before I continue - I'm a white boy... but I'm a white boy who lived in Texas for a few years.  I may not be able to pronounce this stuff - but I now what it all is... and I don't think I would have navigated this menu AT ALL if I hadn't known what it all was.  But I digress.

Guac came out first.  Apparently "made to order at the table" means "prepared at the table" as I felt it needed more salt and probably peppers if my date was ok with the heat - but old boy folded up his dish tray before I got to find out how it was.  But it was while we were waiting for the guac that the first real taste of this chef came out - a complimentary taste of scallop on watermelon.  Very complex, very tasty. The cooked watermelon took on an almost sour quality that paired well with whatever they put on it.

Which brings me to my next gripe - the waitress tried to tell me how it was prepared - but I couldn't hear a thing.  There were two separate music tracks going on - one downstairs, one up, and between that, the crowd and the speed that the waitress tried to explain (bless her) I didn't get any of it.  I tried to follow but couldn't and after twice trying to figure out how something was made gave up and decided to just enjoy.

Up next - the tamales - which weren't tamales as I'd ever had them - more slices of a small loaf of corn bread with filling laced in.  They were good - but I preferred the Xochitl salad my GF went with.  Again - complex and tasty - but not really what I was looking for when I ordered tamales.

Next the Tuna ceviches.  VERY tasty... and probably my favorite part of the meal.  A complex platter of savory and sweet.  My GF had the tostadas - which I think I might have preferred except that I wasn't a hige fan of the mackerel on that platter.

Finally the main course.  Skirt steak was excellently prepared with a few different sauces and served with blue corn tortillas to wrap things up in.  As I wandered around the plate I enjoyed every bit of it separate - but as I began to combine things it had a sort of muttled effect.  At this point I think I was just tired of trying to distinguish so many ingredients in such complex plates.  I was also stuffed beyond imagination before the main course showed up.  I tasted my GFs black bass - the fish was AMAZING... but when I mixed another bite of the plantains and sauce I liked it less.  Again - I think both dishes woud have been AMAZING if I had had them in second course.

Finally dessert was churros and chocolate (defined as churros with litle dishes of sauces) and a crowsie of my GFs caramelized bananna with walnut ice cream.  Both very delishious.  After the spice in the meal I needed the ice cream - and the two dishes together were fabulous.

So in the end - I am being fairly harsh on this place.  I'd say that every plate was great on it's own - it was teh combination where things broke down.  There were also issues where some of the fried foods tasted like they had been left out a while before service... but I guess I expect that maybe showing up late to a dinner service.  But in the end - it felt like a $30 a plate service I paid $60 a plate for... so it's going to get compared to places I would pay that much at... and it simply doesn't match up.

I think if I went back I would go with two courses and dessert and show up at the beginning of service.  I recommend you do the same.  I may give that a try - and if I do I'll update the 'ol Yelp review.

FINAL NOTE: It felt like I should have been dressed better than I was... but everyone else was dressed casually too.

Visited on restaurant week and enjoyed a great four-course meal, including: guacamole, bean and carnitas soup, steak tacos, and flan. The highlights of the meal were the guacamole and the soup, with an honorable mention to the flan (which is always good). The tacos were also fine, just not outstanding. The service and atmosphere were quite welcoming, and I would enjoy another meal at this restaurant.

This is hands down the best Mexican restaurant in Philadelphia, maybe the world. 

I won't tell you what I ordered or what you should get because the answer is: everything & anything.

The cocktail list is fresh, tasty, and imaginative. And the michelada is the best in the city.

Even if you have to save it for a special occasion, Xochitl is a must try.

Another restaurant that lives up to its hype. Sweet. Xochitl (so-cheet) is located in the middle of the pretty cusp of Old City and Society Hill. I love this quaint little place. We went for restaurant week and despite what some here on the yelp say the service was not scaled back. 

The hostess was very friendly, seated up promptly and took our jackets. I wasn't expecting a coat check. +1 for a great hostess and a coat check. It was cold as shit and I personally hate having to sit with my jacket pushed against my back. 

We started with an awesome red sangria (it has tequila in it! w00t!) and they brought out some fresh baked warm and toasty bread (possibly the Xochitl take on pan de agua), with some regular butter and some sp!cy butter. At this point I was already head-over-heels.

Xochitl really went all out this year for restaurant week. Instead of the standard 3 courses for $35 Xochitl offers 4 courses for the same price. That earned them another +1. I started with the pollo con vegetales soup and it was a delight. My fiancée had the corn soup with truffles and goat cheese. She won. That soup knocked my socks off and I want to go home and make it. 

Next up for me was the seafood ceviche. It was served tapas style on little fried corn cakes. There was one of each (Spanish mackerel, octopus, and shrimp) and they were tasty. I used to be the anti-ceviche guy, but after having great experiences at two places now, I am sold.  

Main course is always my favorite course. I ordered the skirt steak medium and it came out medium. +1. It seems no one ever gets my steak right, but tonight Xochitl was running on all fours. The skirt was topped with a special salsa and had a side of pureed turnips. Everything on the plate complemented each other which of coarse is the way it's supposed to be. Often times when a sauce is added to a skirt, it's used to mask the quality of the beef. This was not the case. I tasted every flavor that this dish offered and there I decided that this place wasn't going to do me wrong.

Dessert: Churros w/ two pudding style dipping sauces. I was wow'd. I mean a churro isn't really anything special, and I am not really a dessert guy, but they were warm, tasty, and the little bit of chocolate dip was a great finish to a wonderful dining experience. 

Xochitl earned itself a good 5 star rating from me. Ambiance was great, food was great, server was friendly, host was on point... It feels great to try out a new restaurant and be impressed. $35 for four courses makes it feel even better.

I went here for restaurant week and was very pleased with my experience.
The restaurant itself was small and cozy (bathroom is TINY!). Food was delicious! Aside from the fact that the churros were very bready and undercooked, the rest of the meal was perfect! Be warned! Having a full three courses is a large meal! Especially the flat bread appetizers! They are definitely share-able!! 
As for price, it's a little higher than typical Mexican restaurants, but what can you expect when it's located in Society Hill? Don't be scared of the price! Definitely worth trying out especially during restaurant week!

Although we made a reservation, our table wasn't ready when we got there. The hostess was very nice and genuinely apologetic, but clearly a little flustered by how busy they were - she shrugged and said that we could try to vie for a spot at the bar. Sadly, there were no spots to be had, so we ended up standing next to the bar for a good fifteen minutes until a table opened up. Unfortunately, the table was at the end of the bar, and we had camera flashes going off in our faces for quite a while because of a woman taking MySpace-style photos of herself and her friends. Obviously this wasn't Xochitl's fault, but it's difficult to separate it from the overall dining experience.

I got a margarita, which was fabulous, and the guy I was with got an unusual (but tasty!) cocktail - I think it was the senor barriga. The queso fundido was delicious, and my entree was great (the mole de olla de cerdo - pork, pork, and more pork). 

We ordered two desserts, and we received a complimentary third dessert because of our wait. Not quite free drinks, but still, it was a lovely gesture, and we ended up enjoying the free flan much more than the churros with warm goat's milk, which weren't nearly as luscious as they sounded.

I think we'll return - the food was excellent, and the service was friendly, even if a little uneven.

I don't want to slam the place because the food was good enough but I don't think it lived up to the hype or the price. Maybe I would feel differently had we been upstairs and the atmosphere would have been better. The guac wasn't anything special and half of the avacados in it were too hard to be mashed. The tortilla chips that came with it were good though. I got the skirt steak and it was cooked as I ordered, medium rare.
Food and atmosphere are very pleasing.

Sangria with Ice in it.. seriously?! We asked the hostess and she was like wide eyed with surprise  - "oooohh.. but I have NEVER had any Sangria without Ice"

I gave up on the place after that! lol!!

The guac was fresh, but lacking lemon and salt, we asked them to get some, so we could make it taste better.. lol!!
The chips were fine - fried tortillas instead of normal chips

The queso was just that - CHEESE! With a few peppers thrown in. Nothing memorable.

The Veggie Sope - not my style at all. The masa cake was not seasoned at all. The veggies on top of it was ok, nothing great. 

The Tamale - The mushrooms were perfectly cooked and I loved every bite. But the tamale itself was like super lean, NOT seasoned and too chewy. Not at all like what a real tamale should be! Not flavorful or yummy.

My Coco martini was good - super strong on the coffee flavor, not so much on the tequila though!

The MICHELADA delivered though - it was spicy and strong.

Not sure if I would like to be back here..

Last night might have been my favorite dining experience to date. My 3 friends and I took over a downstairs booth and indulged in far too many dishes. Everything was absolutely perfect - from our server to our food to the cocktails. The dishes came out in excellent timing and with all of the items we tried, not one fell short of amazing.

What we ordered:
Cazuela de Chorizo y Papas - chorizo and potatoes with kale in casserole form. So hearty and delicious!

Tostadas de Tinga - shredded chicken served cold atop a crispy tortilla. These were heavenly.

Ensalada - something light and fresh to cleanse the palate. I loved the jicama!

Atun ceviche - buttery chunks of yellowfin tuna ceviche. Yum.

Platija - maybe the favorite. Fluke ceviche served over those same crispy tortillas. The mild fish was so simply prepared but oh so good.

Carnitas de Pollo - we were really full by this point, but I loved that they embraced the crema for these baby tacos. 

Carrillada de Cerdo - pork cheeks

All in all, you should absolutely go to Xochtil.

Don't buy me gifts, buy me drinks. 
Or dinner. Or both.
That's my birthday motto. 

Two dear friends recently took me to Xochitl (so-cheet) and treated me like a Mexican princess celebrating her quinceanera. And Max, the Monday night, barely legal, bartender, did as well. I never had to ask for a margarita refill and he didn't make me feel bad about how much I could put down. "You're thirsty." What a kind way to call me "drunk."
I'll take it.

I was perfectly happy with just drinking but we ordered guacamole, queso fundido con chorizo and pork cheek tacos. Loved every second of it. Guacamole came with crumbled cheese and tortillas duradas. Please get the chorizo in your queso fundido. Please. And to fortify my pork cheek taco claim, note that the chef and restaurant owners sitting beside us ordered them immediately. If you're in the know, you know you gotta eat these.

Later came the celebratory shots of tequila. 
First: "Cheers to Xochitl, the restaurant and our like-named undergrad Spanish Lit professor!"
Second: "Salud y dinero!" As Lauren and I were about to fearlessly toma el trago, Reenie was relunctant. Ever-so attentive Max grabbed the shots and mixed it with a bit of ice and lime juice for a shot on the rocks. "Cheers to Max!"

Oh, what a night.

On Friday night, I went with 5 friends to Xochitl for dinner to celebrate a friend's birthday, and 4 of the 6 of us ended up with the worst case of food poisoning ever!  The nausea, vomiting, chills, & fever were nasty... And we were all out of comission for about 3 days. All of us had the "special" entree of the night -- the bronzino fish. It tasted great going down, but boy did we all regret it by Saturday night. I'm sorry to say we won't be back to Xochitl again...

Xochitl was my second pick for restaurant week. I don't know why, but this place has been on my list for well over a year. I met up with my good friend Quinn for a Friday night dinner. The menu was exciting, three course plus house made guacamole.

For starters, the drink menu here is decent. There's a large list of house cocktails, a small wine list (36-42 per bottle) and a small, but decent beer list. Drafts are Negro Modello, Dos Eqius Amber and Lager, and Victory Prima Pils and they're all $5.

Throughout the night, our service was just okay, but not what I'd expect of a restaurant this caliber. The one high point of the night though, is when a drink was spilled on our table, someone (the hostess, I think) came over within a minute to help clean up the small mess.

After we ordered our drinks, someone came over and made our order of guacamole table-side. He used a fresh avocado and then asked what we wanted to be added in. We had him add everything, onions, cilantro, some spices, and a few others that I forget. It was good, but certainly not the best I've had.

We split the two appetizers The "Cazuela de chorizo y papas" (casserole of chorizo, potatoes, and kale" sounded really excited but in reality was pretty bland. There's a lot of potential with these ingredients. The same can be said for our other app, the civiche.

The first main was pork tenderloin with Brussel sprouts and turnups. It was a little overdone for my taste, but Quinn really liked it. This dish was decent. Our other main was head on shrimp, and I liked this, but it still lacked a distinct flavor.

Dessert was my favorite part of the meal. I ordered churros and hot chocolate. The churcos were sweet and had a perfect texture. Dipping them in the chocolate was fantastic. Quinn ordered a coconut and quince pie. She liked it a lot, I thought it was okay, but I don't often go for coconut desserts.

Bottom Line: The whole night was good, but not remarkable. I'd rather go to a hole-in-the-wall Mexican place than a fancy one, and I don't even think Xochitl is doing the best Mexican. Still, if you find yourself here, you won't be disappointed.

The food was good, the service was good - the Guacamole was above average.

My issue - which will cause me to probably go elsewhere in the future was their Happy Hour policy. You can get happy hour pricing at the bar, in the bar area, outside, but not in the seated dining area.  It isn't has if I was asking them to walk any further.

What blew my mind was being told that it "would only cost me $3 more" for the same drink.  

I can understand that they do not want people just sitting, drinking and not ordering food in that area - easily solved with a minimum food purchase. We were also the only ones seated in that area for close to 30 min - and in the hour we were there - there were only 2 tables occupied (probably no one wanted to pay the extra $3).

It is worth considering if you are close and don't want to walk another couple of blocks - but there are a number of other options around that don't have this Happy Hour policy. Personally lost me as a future customer.

I understand why the stars might be lower as the menu is limited and this is not the place I would pick for authentic Mexican food. 

Came here for a last minute reservation on a Saturday night and when we arrived before our table was ready the hostess let us order togo cocktails to walk around with a sip. The yucca fries were delicious and the platanos fritos were good but are unexpectedly sweet not savory! Would order again but as more of a desert option

This is my first yelp post ever. Came here for restaurant week. I had normal expectations. The menu says made to order guacamole per table. We had 6 people, so I'm thinking either 2 guacamole (since it was 2 tables put together) or at least a big portion. No (and we even asked). A 2-top and 3-top were seated at least 15 minutes after us. They received all of their food before we did, including their appetizers before my sangria. Out of 6 people, 1 person thought their meal was "decent." My dessert was literally thawed (not even heated) and put on a plate. I'm just overall, so disappointed. You could go just about anywhere else with $$$ and get better food.

I've been hearing about this place for a while and the name was quite intriguing. My friend & I visited tonight (Friday) for happy hour between 5-7. The bar staff is very very friendly. the moment I sat down the bartender gave me a class of ice water and took my drink order. My friend and I ordered the $5 house margaritas and queso fundido. The margaritas were made with fresh limes and chilled w/ crushed ice. I am not a great fan of saccharine sour mix that you would most likely get at a chilis or applebees so this was perfect for my taste buds. The queso fundido was different than anything i would get at a chain hispanic restaurant which are more cheese whiz like. I loved the chihuahua cheese and grilled peppers. The tortillas were piping hot and delicious. The platter could have maybe used some stronger flavors on the plate like some figs or roasted garlic (not both) to go with the mild flavor of the cheese. The bartender Nick was also very friendly and a good conversationalist. Overall - a great time with good drinks over a nice appetizer.

I was so wowed by this meal, I can't wait to return. I had a coupon and wanted Mexican food...plus there were a lot of good reviews. The restaurant is non-descript but very cozy. I was kind of annoyed that their happy hour was only if you sat in the bar, but oh well. I ordered the house margarita and for dinner, we had the moljacete ($28 for two). The entrée was a mixture of meats and veggies with warm corn tortillas. It was spicy but fantastic. We also ordered the rice with manchego...it had corn in too, ugh, so yummy. My daughter's cheese quesadilla was good, too. We also ordered the guac and added goat cheese. Delicious. My margarita was $9 and really good. It was a generous size, too, and I left feeling a little tipsy. Score!! 

I loved our meal. Prices are a little steep but the food is well worth it.

*This review is for drinks only.

Came here for after dinner drinks and sat at the bar.  My husband got a cocktail made with rye whiskey and orange bitters.  It had something a bit spicy in it too, which gave it a bit of a kick, which was different as far as rye whiskey drinks go.  I settled on a glass of wine.  The atmosphere is sort of chill, but then they have TV's at the bar, so it's hard not to think you're at a sports bar.  If they got rid of the TV's, the place would feel more classy, but perhaps that's not the vibe they're going for?  Actually, I'm not quite sure the vibe they are trying to achieve here.  It's confusing.

Drinks are priced appropriately for the area.  The service was just okay - no one was super friendly or unfriendly.  I would like to try their guacamole next time I'm in the area.

Xochitl is by far the best Mexican restaurant in Philadelphia. Their spicy margs are to die for and are not the typical out of the tap, pre-made, sugar drinks. They are prepared with their 2 month, jalapeño infused, tequila - made to order. My favorite thing on the menu is the guacamole which you can personalize to how you like. The staff is beyond accommodating and friendly. They make you feel like you're at your neighborhood bar no matter where you're coming from. I highly recommend checking them out!

First off, they can really work on their customer service. My mom, fiancée and I came here for dinner. It was around 530 on Friday so they still had happy hour going on. They said we couldn't order happy hour drinks at the table so I went up to the bar to order the drinks for my party. (Why they make this arbitrary rule, no one knows.) Anyway I order the 3 drinks at the bar and the manager comes up to me and tells me he will give me these drinks on happy hour but any other drinks will need to be ordered from the table where there isn't happy hour. Mind you the drinks come from the same bar. This obviously rubs me the wrong way to begin with. 

Next, my mom and I order tacos. They were mediocre. This is a Mexican restaurant so we order a side of salsa each for our  bland tacos. The waitress says nothing about an additional charge at this point or that she recommend we get one since the sizes are large. She brings out 2 pretty large containers of salsa which we only use a scoop of each. Once the bill comes out we realize she charged us $4 for salsa. We point out the $4 charge to our waitress who then says "you wanted it didn't you?" Since she couldn't handle the situation she brings her manager out (same guy as before). He proceeds to argue over this salsa surcharge.... Naming other restaurants that charge for salsa and chips. I'm in shock at this point. When he finally realizes that we ordered side salsa and she charged us for the menu price of 2 salsa and chip containers he starts to back away from his argument. 

Charging for salsa is one thing but not being transparent, nickel and dimming your customers and poor customer service with poor performing food is another.
Carnitas tacos left me speechless, in a good way. Sat downstairs, good attentive service and would totally go back.

Went with a large group for a birthday and it was overall a great experience! 

We sat in the basement which was almost completely to ourselves. Nice decor and an extremely nice and attentive server who tried to make conversation with us the whole night. The customized guacamole concept is nice. We had the chipotle chilis which gave a nice smoky flavor to it with roasted tomatoes, cilantro and onions and cheese and it was delicious and had a nice kick to it too. My brisket enchiladas were decent enough but a relatively large portion size. The random onions potato and sausage thing that came with it was absolutely delicious though! 

Prices are a bit steep for the quality of food you get although I guess it is a fancier place. I had the guava margarita and it didn't taste much like anything other than a regular margarita, which wasn't bad but not what I was expecting. 

Overall a good experience with the guacamole and random side dish as standouts. If you want mexican food and a nice night out this is a good option but if you just want good food you're probably better served elsewhere.

Dinner

Service: 1.5 - we had to wait for 25 mins to order, and it wasn't packed. And had to ask again later in order to get our guac and chips. They then forgot our main orders and had to ask again. Bartender was gracious and seemed to help the waitress after we pointed it out when he delivered our drinks.
Drinks: 5 
Chips: 4.5
Salsa Roja: 2 - too close to tomato sauce, which seems to be common for Philly Mexican restaurants
Guac: 3 - could use some citrus
Corn: 4
Chicken Tacos: 3 - overly sauced
Shrimp Tacos: 4.5 

Still searching for a great Philly Mexican restaurant

Beautiful ambience, and delicious food! Very knowledgable waitstaff and great tequila selection. The Mexican style corn and rice & manchego are delicious. We got tacos and were pleased with the size and flavors. The mole chicken drummettes are just wonderful. Huge plus is that they have a large amount of gluten free options available. We will for sure be back next time we're in Philly!!

I was very excited to try out Xochitl, the menu looked delicious and I'd heard so many great reviews from friends. I'm happy to report it didn't disappoint. It's in such a beautiful little corner of Headhouse Square. 

I actually screwed up on the reservation and made it for the wrong day so we showed up on a Sunday without an actual reservation. However they were able to seat us at a small table in the bar area. It worked out for the best because we were able to get the happy hour specials. I had a couple margaritas and they were really fantastic. They were definitely fresh. 

For an appetizer we had one of the guacamole specials that included pine nuts and cilantro. It was mouth watering. It they would have handed me a vat full of it and a spatula I would have polished it off. My only gripe about it at check time is that it cost $13, when regular tableside guac cost $8. Next time I think we'll just go with the traditional guacamole. 

For dinner I had the Bistec Azteca, which was a skirt steak with avocado fries. The steak was tender and delicious, although not remarkable. The star of the show was the avocado fries. Seriously. Why have I never had this before? Why have I never made this before? The hot avocado inside the fried outside was creamy and absolutely phenomenal. Thinking of it right now is making me hungry. Truly the star of the night. 

My husband had the pork tenderloin. Of the two meats I preferred his, the seasoning was strong, and I definitely recommend. 

For dessert we had churros with chocolate dipping sauce. They were your traditional churros and brought us back to churros for breakfast in Mexico. 

Xochitl is definitely my favorite Mexican restaurant in the city.

Came here with three friends using a Groupon. The Groupon was for four courses (guacamole, appetizer, entry and dessert) with paired wines. Everything we had was so delicious! We were even able to customize our guacamole which was awesome. We each had a different entree and we all loved what we ordered. Two of us also had margaritas which were incredible. Highly recommend this place and cannot wait to go back, it's a hidden gem for sure!

I live for guacamole...they may have the best I've ever had. Who would have thought pomegranate seeds would pair so beautifully with guac!? The food, margaritas and atmosphere are all top-notch as well!

Haven't had Mexican in a while so was pretty excited. Service was OK our server didn't come over much. The hostess Dana with glasses and long brown hair was what made our experience better. She made sure everything was ok multiple times more than our server. I couldn't eat my entree I ordered at first because it didn't taste ok and tasted like BBQ and that wasn't in the description. The guacamole was awesome though. If Dana wasn't so peppy and super nice and understanding of me not liking my first meal I probably would have just finished my beer and not ordered anything else. We wanted to give the tip to Dana but she had gone home after her shift.
Eat the four cheese empanadas and dessert. Everything else is decent. Not worth the price.

This place is quite the find, it was recommended to us by a friend and it is our definitely go to place for all occasions. Best guacamole ever!!! 

The three day prep chicken is my all time favorite dish washed down with margaritas on the rocks or the el pepino, tequila infused cucumber drink with jalapeños and salt. Hits all the senses. 

I love this place and when in philly will always try to get there!!

I came here for happy hour a couple years ago and for dinner on a Saturday night more recently. It's an upscale, romantic place (mood lighting and all..), perfect for a cute date night (when you want to splurge a little) =)

Mexican is always my favorite and I was impressed with my "Amarillo" margarita which tasted like fresh pineapple and was strong. The drinks all sounded amazing, I wanted to try all of them! I think my date had one of the classic margaritas which he also liked. We split brisket enchiladas and chicken tacos. I rarely think chicken tacos are better than other types of meat tacos and I was blown away by the chicken tacos... Packed with flavor! The enchiladas were also delicious and I loved the enchilada sauce. We were too full for dessert! Can't wait to go back sometime...

I have very mixed feelings about this place. These are the same owners of Zahav which I adored and maybe my expectations were just a tad high..

The atmosphere (and our waitress) was adorable but the food was ....just ok. There were five of us and we all got the sabor which is 3 courses for each person. Aside from the dessert, everything is gluten free so i MADE SURE we all ordered different dishes so we could taste a good portion of the menu. My family is hard to please but their major complaint was "it's a Mexican place and the food isn't spicy!" I thought the guac (made table side) was good but again people complained no taste. 

I asked everyone what they thought collectively were their faves. For the appetizer, the soup and the main dish, the salmon. Agreed both dishes were excellent. but you don't go to a Mexican spot for salmon amirite?

I ate here for restaurant week. The restaurant is cute, very clean, small in a nice way. The server we had was a little uninformed as far as what the wines were like and what exactly was in every dish, but that's forgivable.

The food? Not so much. Overall, everything tasted old. I had a salmon ceviche that tasted like it had been in the fridge for over a week. My main course, a steak dish, was inedible. The steak, again, tasted OLD and the frying the avocados rendered them oily and flavorless. There was also some sort of "enchilada" on the plate that tasted like it was made from raw potatoes. The churros for desert were too doughy and over seasoned with sugar and cinnamon.

I'd probably stop in here for drinks, but the food was definitely a waste of time.

The service was really bad and the food was not good at all I'm very disappointed. They served me raw shrimp
And the Mgr didn't really address it. They were busy but not that busy at all. Don't come here.
Try the Xochitl Margarita.. It's amazing! Delicious authentic Mexican cuisine.

I want to love this place. It's adorably located on head house square, sandwiched between Bloomsday and Malbec. Also, not many Mexican restaurants nearby to compete with. 

So why is this only 3 stars? The food is okay. The drinks are okay. The service is okay. That's what gets you 3 stars. It's edible and doesn't appear unclean. 

Advice: capitalize on the new crowds heading this way for Bloomsday. Hire friendlier, more charismatic bartenders. Do you want to be a bar that has TVs? Then be a bar that has TVs. This means playing sports, listening to customers that want certain things played, have game day specials, etc. If you don't want to be a bar that has TVs, then get rid of them. Finally, can't stress this one enough - get on Instagram! And post daily about your TVs, new bartenders, and amazing food, drink specials and events.

Great tacos! The drinks were fantastic as well, I think I enjoyed the sangria better than the margs though. Went here for a group date and enjoyed the atmostphere though the service was a bit slow. The fish tacos are grilled though and a bit fishy for my taste, but the gauc was perfect. You even get to fill out a card with your custom guacamole. So fun!

Cinco De Mayo!

Any excuse to eat Mexican and enjoy Sangria +/- Cerveza is good to me!

I wanted to try someplace new and came across Xochitl.  I was SOLD when I saw that they have tamales (klinda hard to come across).
Made a reservation for two using the open table app.

The place is a bit cramped and there is a downstairs seating area (though I didn't see it).
We were greeted and seated rapidly however it did take a bit of time for a server to come over and take even out drink orders.

I started with the Sangria which was made with tequila.  When I make Sangria it is usually qith gin or triple sec but this was a nice change.  It was fruity and refreshing.  I went to the cervesa afterwards because I love to try new beers and they had a good selection of Mexican beer that I hadn't tried before.

I believe you MUST have the guacamole when coming here.  There is a small card on the table (see pic) and you check off teh things you would like to be mixed into the guac.  So though it is not prepared table side they make it to your liking.

Appetizer: shared the tuna cerviche.  This was a play on the typical cerviche I have had as well.  It was served with thin slices of tuna and seasoned with chunks of onions, tomatoes etc.  It was ok.

Entree's:  Fish tacos and mushroom tamale--both were just ok

There is a bathroom nestled in the corner behind the bar.  This is directly across from the kitchen entrance.  There is literally no room between the bathroom door and the entrance and I was smacked with the kitchen door.  I was a little shocked and the girl who came out of the kitchen did not even apologize!

Overall, I think I would prefer to try another Mexican place or visit one that I have enjoyed more in the past.

Had been wanting to try this place and after a conversation at a NYE party with someone who raved about it, we decided to give it a go.  Sadly, it didn't live up to the hype.

First impression was good.  The place was welcoming and had good ambiance.  We were seated quickly and the hostess was friendly.  Few minutes later hostess comes back as our waitress.  I noticed some cocktails were $9 and some were $24.  To me that either means some are sharable fishbowls or some are top shelf.  I asked the waitress what sizes the cocktails come in and she just stared at me.  So I clarified, asking in terms of ounces.  More awkward staring and she finally said she didn't know.  Ok.  No offer to walk 10 feet over to the bar and find out.  Cool.  I guess I'll be surprised when I order this Margarita... Got the perfect margarita and boyfriend got some pineapple thing.  Mine was strong but not great.  I wasn't a fan of his, but whatever.  Not my drink.  

We got the build your own guac and the red snapper ceviche as starters.  The guac was perfect.  Seriously great.  That's about it.  The ceviche was plated well and visually appealing, but that's it.  I took one bite and said "nope".  Boyfriend finished it because he was starving but didn't love it.  It was a bit overpriced, and tasted more like a seafood salad than a ceviche.  It really missed the light fresh flavors that are meant to come with citrus and onion and just felt heavy and overly fishy.  Not how I prefer ceviche, which is something we eat once every few weeks.  (I will point out that we didn't complain and it was gone when she collected the plates, so she likely had no idea we weren't satisfied and if you don't speak up, they can't fix it, so that's on us) 

I was going to order the fish tacos but learned they were out.  Was thinking about the lamb but they were out of that too.  After that I felt pressured to order so I just got a salad thinking it would be pretty hard to screw up.  Wrong again.  It looked like it would have been great if it had a different dressing and base.  The toppings (tomato, radish) were fresh and looked good but the spinach/lettuce was a bowl of wilted soggy slop.  I really wasn't a fan of the dressing; probably should have gotten it on the side.  Tried my boyfriends' spicy tacos.  Got no spice (and I'm a weenie when it comes to spices usually).  Ordered a different cocktail, something with jalepeno.  It was just ok.  Not bad but not great.  

I felt like there was a lot of time where we were just sitting & waiting for her to come back.  They weren't terribly busy but I think she was the only server; didn't see anyone else. At nearly $100 for 2 of us I don't think we'll be back.

Went here during restaurant week and what I'm about to tell you may sound weird (judge me accordingly) but I don't like dessert. 

*Insert dramatic pause for readers disappointment**

As I was saying... because I don't like dessert every time I go to fixed menu/3 course places I ask to skip the dessert and have two appetizers instead. Other than the weird head tilt where they look confused and judgmental they have all obliged. This place was the first to say no. A little disappointed about that..

The place/ambiance was really nice. A great date spot. Because of that, I had high expectations of the food which sadly were never met. The food wasn't bad by any means but it also wasn't good. I'n a city with so many options especially at this price point, I would go elsewhere for fancier Mexican food (El Vez is an easy alternative).

The one thing this place had going for it was the make your own guacamole. Unique option and it came out pretty quickly.
