Amazing margs! Would go back for the drinks alone...but the civieches and other apps are delicious as well.  The bartenders are friendly and let us take up 4 seats at the bar for a good part of a busy evening...just casually sipping and snacking at our leisure.  It's pretty easy to rack up a large tab here without realizing it...but the overall experience makes it worth it!

Went to Xochitl earlier this month and experienced a few good things and a few bad things about this restaurant.  

Pros: Guacamole was excellent, well prepared and well seasoned.  The perfect margarita was delicious, although on the expensive side.

Cons: Service was awful.  It took over an hour to get our main entrees and the size and quality was pathetic. The chicken tacos (around $15) were tiny with little meat and even less flavor.  

Overall, the ambiance is very nice but the quality of food and service is lacking.

If it weren't for restaurant week, I would have given Xochitl five stars. Alas, their restaurant week menu feels like a scam, and you don't get your money's worth. Portions are watered down half size versions of their full menu. You are better off ordering off their full menu and paying close to the same thing (sans desserts, which aren't that good anyway) and getting double the food. DON'T COME HERE FOR RESTAURANT WEEK.

That being said, their jalapeno corn puree is something I dream about. It is by far the best way I've ever had corn prepared in my life. I've been to Xochitl twice, and I tend to be a somewhat boring person in that if I find a dish I really like, I'll often go back and order the same thing. So basically, both times I've gone there, I've ordered the same thing. I guess that's why I was so incredibly disappointed by the Restaurant Week menu, as I've had the same thing off the regular menu and it was waaaaaaaay better.

For a starter, the ahi tuna ceviche was great. Perfect spice, although it could probably use a few more chips - they seemed like they were more for garnish than for actually scooping up the ceviche. Restaurant week version gave you a smaller portion with even fewer chips, and didn't seem nearly as spicy, unfortunately.

El Dorado was my main - salmon with that delicious corn puree I previously mentioned, with a tomatillo salad. If you order it regular, you get a huge portion of salmon which is stuffed with crab. The tomatillos in the salad are strangely good, the acid of the tomatillos pairs perfectly with the sweetness of the corn. The disappointing restaurant week version of the meal comes with a tiny piece of salmon, not stuffed, with the corn and a few leaves of lettuce thrown on top, with nary a tomatillo to be found. I guess you might begin to see why I was quite disappointed with Restaurant Week!

All in all, I think the food at Xochitl is great. Everyone seems friendly and the service is decent. I would just strongly advise to not order off the Restaurant Week menu, as it really appears to be not worth the money when you compare it to the dishes on the full menu, otherwise you may find yourself as disappointed as I was on my second visit.

I wouldn't come back here again. It was mediocre at best. 

We came here a lonnnng time ago. Decided to give it a try on a Saturday around 8:00. It was restaurant week. I didn't like the appetizer or dessert options so I opted to just order off of the regular menu. My fiancé ordered from the restaurant week menu and regretted it because he didn't like his appetizer or dessert so it wasn't really worth it. 

The tables inside are super on top of each other. I hate that so we dined outside. The tables are way too small. We are both tall so every time I tried to cross my legs under the table my knees would hit the table and shake it. I kept forgetting so it kept happening...every. Time. 

Our server did not introduce herself. She poured us water at first without saying anything. Eventually I asked her for a regular menu not knowing if she was just an assistant that brings water, clears tables, etc. or our actual waitress. Eventually we realized she was our waitress. She was nice and got the job done but the service was nothing to rave about. 

We filled out our card to customize our guacamole. It was very spicy. It was good but I've had better. A small portion for the price. Not enough chips...we had to ask for more. 

My fiancé got the ceviche which oddly enough wasn't served with anything to dip except for two small plantain chips. He said it was fishy. 

I thought the restaurant week menu was supposed to be the same size portions as the regular menu but I got veggie enchiladas and he got chicken enchiladas and my dish was served with 3, his with 2. My tomatillo sauce was good but the whole dish was cold. I asked what vegetables were in my veggie enchiladas but she said she didn't know and would have to ask. I didn't feel like waiting so I told her not to worry about it. I should have waited because I never would have ordered them in a million years. It was the strangest grouping of veggies I've ever gotten in a veggie enchilada. Broccoli, cauliflower, potatoes, zucchini. Ugh. Not good at all. Who puts potatoes in a veggie enchilada?!?

My fiancé got the tres leches cake for dessert. Again...nasty. It was the strangest texture ever. It tasted like rice pudding. Horrible. He regretted it and would never want to eat it again. 

The bathroom is soooooooo small. I mean, SMALL. like airplane bathroom small. I hated every second of being in it. It's just outside the kitchen, too. Bleh. 

We both agreed that we wouldn't have the desire to ever return here.

I've been here once before, they have since updated their menu.  They now have a tasting menu for $23 per person which includes guac and chips, an app, and one taco, with the option to add ceviche ($9) or dessert ($5).  

When I went, I chose to not do the tasting menu simply because I didn't want the guacamole.  I ordered the empanadas ($7) as an appetizer and the carnitas de pollo tacos ($10)- total $17.  Both were SO good, such an interesting take on Mexican fare.  The margaritas were delicious as ever, nothing's changed there.  Plus, I was STUFFED even without the guacomole. 

I guess my point is, if you want to eat a delicious, inventive dinner and are strapped for cash, you can skip the tasting menu and save a few bucks without sacrificing your taste buds and belly.

Hands down the best margarita I've ever had. The bartender (manager?  Owner?  Sorry we didn't get his name) infuses tequila with deliciousness. I had two of the margaritas with jalapeño, basil, cucumber and lime goodness. Just the right amount of heat. 

The food was mouthwatering as well - the spicy brisket tacos were to die for. The guacamole, with optional ingredients, was fresh and yummy!

This might have been one of the worst experiences i have ever had in the city. Went here Saturday night for dinner. We had a party of 5. Dinner took 2.5 hours. We only ordered Guacamole and tacos. They probably went slow so we would keep ordering $10+ margaritas, which are a total rip off.  When we asked the bar tender if there was anything he could do to compensate us for our patience, the manager came over and treated us like we had never been out to dinner before and didn't even apologize. Told us that it was the Industry standard to serve shitty food and make you wait hours to get it. 

 I would not recommend this restaurant to one of my enemies, i am not that mean. DO NOT GO HERE!!!! THE WORST RESTAURANT IN THE CITY!!! THE FOOD WAS SUB PAR, THE SERVICE WAS SLOW AND THE EMPLOYEES RUDE!!! I RATHER EAT AT TACO BELL THAN AT THIS RESTAURANT!!  HORRIBLE HORRIBLE HORRIBLE!!! I FEEL BAD FOR ANYBODY THAT GOES HERE.

Went here after a long day at the Convention Center. The place is small but comfortable. It was definitely not cheap but I will say, the margaritas were tasty albeit a tad small. I miss California margaritas.......

The guacamole was handmade and was very good albeit small in portion size. I was unable to mix tacos which was disappointing as I always like to try 3 different kinds so as to know what to order next time. I settled on the shrimp tacos. They were very good. I would suggest allowing one to mix and match as I chicken and carnitas tacos along with a shrimp would have been perfect. Such is life.

The waiter was awesome and gave us the VIP discount which was appreciated. Appropriate tipping was then made. Would I go back? Yes. It is not the west coast but it was not bad!
The first time I was here I thought this place was a 5 Star.  Second time around not so much.  Food did not seem as magnificent as it was before. I did have the fried chicken though.....

I can't BELIEVE I didn't review the original incarnation of Xochitl. 

Probably because it was my go-to first date place and it was on the QT. Then I fell out of the habit of dating. 

Then there was the overly long relationship with speed dial and Little Italy Pizza. 

Anyway, New Year ...

Like many here I approached the new Xochitl with trepidation/shoulder chip. I just really liked what we had and wasn't ready to move on. So for those of you who like me, knew the old and are curious about the new (well, it's 6 months new), this review is for you.

Atmosphere is still great.

Service improved vastly after the sh!tty dip earlier this year.

Menu kept some of the greats from before but changed it up and got slightly less adventurous. At first blush it reads more basic (blah blah blah tacos, tamales) but the ingredients and execution keeps it all interesting.

They had the nerve to remove the queen bee item from the former menu, Tortilla Soup, BUT they talked me off the ledge when they revealed it was the night's special. I haven't tried their version, but based on how they handled the other dishes, I feel reasonably confident they'll do it well.

The red sangria got a makeover from brush-teeth drinking glass to a stem glass with a half straw with red grape halves. Still works though drinking it with the straw makes me feel so ... effete. Ole.

The guacamole (I got the regular - I can't abide by the mix-ins concept popularized by lame El Vez) was suprisingly excellent - complex flavors, good crunch, deceptively rich. The tortilla chips were very fine - thick cut.  But not stellar. I wanted them to be a little warm. Or a little lime. Or both.

The queso fundido (two versions, adobe peppers or chorizo - I did the peppers) was tasty but imperfect. It was a little greasy - sort of ridiculous complaint given molten cheese IS grease. It formed a nice cheesy crust which to me is grade A fat-girl eating. The tortillas tasted a little pre-fab, which brought the dish down a notch.

The fried chicken was a mixed bag. As someone else mentioned the menu takes pains to let you know how involved the preparation is. The final product is very good though maybe not a panty wetter. It's moist from the 40 days and nights of marinating but not necessarily flavorful. And the chili sauce lacing visual resembled the way a Bennigan's would drizzle icing on a danish. It's kind of pedestrian and a wood deflator. The accompanying corn bread was wonderful: some nice chewy corn, good rough texture while the overall effect remained moist. I wanted the bread to be warmer, but you can't have it all. The side greens with chorizo is a miss. Way too much chorizo and a little heavy on the vinegar. I live for greens but I'm not so sure about these.

But clearly I was happy with my meal & overall experience (loved the waitress - friendly, knowledgeable, not at all pushy, efficient) so I asked if they had dessert and ... they do. I got this roiling hot chocolate cake in a ramekin (not the molten style - I believe that concept has finally inched its way to restaurant heaven) but the real news here is the topping. A dense shlag-style cinnamon whipped cream plopped on top the size of a latin nut sack. And it was f!cking amazing. Huge bonus points for the God smart enough not to add sugar to the whipped cream. So much better sans sugar. PS that cake was unbelievably delicious and my new, larger waist size can prove it.

Let's review:
great atmosphere, service and red sangria
great guac
decent queso fundido - let's say B+
reasonable fried chicken - let's say B+
thunderously perfect chocolate cake with a nipple pincher of cinnamon whipped cream throwdown

Xochitl happily remains on the regular rotation.

Postscript, I am so annoyed by any review that starts with some complaint about not being happy about a Groupon. I wish Yelp had a sort feature to remove them.

What a faaabulous dinner! I am not only talking about the company I was with, but mostly about the food, drinks and service. We came as a group of 5 and were seated at a nice, isolated table in the back of the bar. Our server pronounced all the drinks and specials as I would assume to be the correct way.  

We started with beers, the blood orange margarita (not my fav, bleh) and the Bochito margarita (hello new best friend). Though the vegetarian options were limited (one entree) the two vegetarians in the group split the order and it worked out. I can't recall exactly what my friends ordered so I'll tell you about what my veggie friend and I shared.

First of all, gauc for the table. Just do it. 'Nuff said.

For starters: 
--Sopa Azteca - by far my favorite thing on the menu. So yummy and since we split the portion it was the perfect size. 
--Ensalada - also very good but I wanted to keep eating my sopa and not get rid of the taste in my mouth. In hindsight, I wish I had spent a little more time with the salad, I feel guilty I neglected it.

Entree:
There was only one vegetarian entree so of course that is what we ordered. But we were not disappointed!!!! My mouth is watering thinking about the tamales. There were two different kinds - the chestnut and the huitlacoche, or 'corn fungus'. I didn't get the try the huitlacoche because we didn't realize both tamales were different until we had each devoured the one in front of us. Anyway, no complaints from the friend who did eat it.

Sweets:
Churros with hot chocolate =] I don't need to elaborate.

I cannot wait to come back!! Even if just for the drinks..there were so many more I wanted to try.

WARNING: DO (not) UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES CONSUME MORE THAN TWO MARGARITAS FROM XOCHITL (or else you might end up too drunk to stumble your way to the Society Hill parking lot...ergo risking your status...in...well...society. "Hello chaps, I've just had 3 drinks and now I'm a blithering idiot." Stumble, stumble, fall.) 

The Perfect Margarita is, indeed, perfect...and is complimented very nicely by chipotle salt...you need salt to retain the water so you don't dehydrate yourself and end up as above. 

The build your own guacamole is a fun concept: I've always wanted to blend black truffles and Mexican onion in an avocado puree. But unfortunately, the guacamole had its tush handed to it by the best fried tortilla chips I've stuffed my face with. Double layered and perfectly salty, these chips are fried to light gold perfection, and it's guaranteed you'll leave the basket empty...with nothing but grease remnants staining the red napkin to let you know who's been where.

The mushroom tamale dish was more like one long skinny tamale topped with dollops of soft Mexican white cheese. Thick and smooth, the tamale exuded a mild corn flavor, and served as the ultimate compliment to the umami pile of sautéed mushrooms accompanying it.

Mediocre and overpriced. It used to be great but don't be fooled. Everything has gone downhill here but the prices. 

My party of six waited almost two hours to be served -- after being subjected to a surly hostess, a waiter who didn't take drink or food orders till we got up and found him, and unclean bathrooms with graffiti on the walls. 

The manager gave us a free pitcher of sangria as an apology for poor service, but it was too little too late. Food was about on par with Applebee's but pricier. 

I hope someone saves this sinking ship but in the meantime look elsewhere for upscale Mexican.

The bartender made this place the best experience for me.  My family and I discovered this place in Philly while we were looking for a nice restaurant to celebrate.  

You know a good restaurant if they have a good bartender and a good bartender that attends to your needs without you having to ask.  

I had the cuban sandwich which was awesome, guacamole was excellent as well, the bartender continued to refill my moms margarita all night!  Great service, great food, nice place for a evening out but nothing too formal!

Pricey, but worth trying out one of the more innovative Mexican places in town. You will not find pico de gallo, avocado, or mole sauce over everything. Xochitl's menu is creative and deliberate, better than most places where the side dishes and appetizers are simply afterthoughts. 

Drinks: The Michelada is beer spiked with lime juice and chile powder. Definitely interesting - I think you'll love it or hate it. I loved it. Margarita's are decent but a tad pricey and they have an extensive tequila menu. 

Appetizers: Try the ceviches! The most traditional is the "Vuelve a la Vida" with fresh scallops, squid, pieces of fish marinated in lime juice. I thought their best one was scallops with watermelon - very thinly sliced and perfectly sweet together. Sopes and Tamales are miniature and cute, worth a try but not spectacular. 

Entrees: I went with 5 other people who all ordered different things. I thought all the entrees were good and filling. The shrimp dish is impressive - huge shrimp with heads left on in a very savory sauce. It was definitely the one that had the "Wow" factor. 
 
4.5 stars I would say. Only minus is the price and difficulty in getting a reservation.

I've wanted to go here for awhile now - ever since I saw their sign that said "soup of the day: tequila with H2O croutons." We went for restaurant week a bit ago, and we were surprised to see how tiny it is. We got margs and sangria at the bar for happy hour, and both were very much to our liking.

They have a customizable guacamole option, which we opted out of this time, but it looks really fun! We were fans of the tortilla soup and the ceviche tostadas we had to start. Our entrees were a little smaller than we had guessed, but they were quite good nonetheless. I enjoyed my shrimp tacos. They had a nice background spice that lasted throughout eating them. They were reminiscent of the shrimp tacos at El Vez (which is a good thing!). We got rice pudding and a chocolate flan for dessert. The flan was more firm than we were used to but good as well!

I went to Xochitl with the girls in my supper club a few months ago.  From the moment we walked in, we just got a weird vibe - the hostess was kind of rude, the waitresses were confused as to who was serving our table (we gave our drink orders and literally 2 seconds later a different waitress was standing at our table asking what we would like to drink...confusing!).  

The restaurant in itself is cute, intimate (VERY small), and colorful.  We were seated at a back table and it was uncomfortably hot - but it wasn't hot outside, go figure.  The place was really loud, too.  

We all took advantage of the $32 guac & chips, appetizer, and entree special (El Sabor).  First of all, the guacamole is made tableside and is really, really good. I got the Ensalada app, which I thought was light, refreshing, and flavorful.  For dinner, I got the falda de res - so good. 
Other appetizers we got were:  chorizo (sausage) with kale - it was alright, and the queso fundido (don't do it), which was basically a pile of melted cheese, it was gross.  Other entrees - I don't even remember, which probably means that they weren't all that memorable (and I didn't order them).  I enjoyed my meal, but my friends were not impressed with theirs.  On the plus side - the drinks were delish!  I'm not sure that I want to go back....too pricey, not enough food, and cramped quarters!

I went here for drinks and an appetizer before our night out....it turned out this was part of our night out because the margaritas were STRONG and even got hooked up with an extra one later.

The ceviche was wonderful. I wish we would have stayed there because we got totally bombed at the Plough and the Stars after but the prices were gonna bankrupt me and the last thing I need to do is spend all my money on alcohol when I have kids at home to feed
The extra hookup was nice though....

I found the margaritas there to be pricey for my budget, but the one top shelf agave I did order ($12) as suggested by the bartender, was delicious. The next one, a well margarita, had a dirty taste...I guess I don't like their well tequila. (When do I ever like well tequila?)

I would go back sometime to try the food, but it's not something I would go out of my way for, especially since I don't live in the area. I would say go to this place if you have lots of money to burn and enjoy trendy places. The decor was nice and reminded me of old-world Spain. I must say going on Thursday was good for the half-price food. Next time I'll go there to eat, not to drink.

I

I've been to Xochitl a few times during Covid and it's a really great option as they have seating in the middle/covered structure of Headhouse Square. Lately as it getting colder it's becoming a really great spot with heatlamps. Super nice staff with really good food. Their signature guacamole is awesome. Good margaritas, ceviche and entrees.

Very under impressed the guacamole was brown.  The red salsa was more like a tomato sauce.  The chicken tacos were bland.  My date had the short rib tacos that were supposed to have chimchurri but it was missing and they were also bland.  Ehhhhh  The ambiance is beautiful I'm soo disappointed

Service was average. Prices are overpriced. Husband's chicken enchiladas were average. My veggie enchiladas were absolutely disgusting! The mango margarita was really good and at least helped wash down nasty food. I paid 8 dollars for the margarita because it was a cinco de mayo special. The glass was really small about 6 ounces tops filled mostly with ice. Definitely not coming again and absolutely would not recommend. Not sure how they have 4.2 stars on open table but yelp is more accurate.

Probably the best Mexican restaurant I have ever dined at.  The food and drink transported me back to my last trip to Riviera Maya.  Upscale taste, no messy tex-mex style food.

The food was fresh and appropriately spicy (Goldilock's level, not too hot, not too bland...just right.  The house margarita sent me to Bed Bath and Beyond and Acme to have only fresh squeezed limes and simple syrup in any drinks I make for myself at home.  

I have dined here twice.  The first trip, our actual seating did not occur until about 45 minutes after our reservation (which we were prompt for).  The house comped our drinks during the wait.  It was a bright gesture that brought me back a 2nd time.  Both times, the dining experience has been smooth and delicious.  I have already scheduled a 3rd visit.

The guacamole is the best item on their menu. Everything else tastes good, but unfortunately, the fish tacos and the carne asada tacos were not as outstanding. 

Nice ambiance and good venue for parties ranging from 2-8.

I didn't eat food at xochitl, so I can't speak for that- I just stopped in for a quick after dinner drink. The space wasn't crowded or overwhelming, just a good place to hang out with one or two people and chat in a cool, calm environment. This is the perfect bar to come to if you just want to chat and relax, not go to a crazy packed place with loud music and crowds. I'd come back for sure!

My girlfriend and I came here last night had a awesome time! we were visiting philly and was looking where to eat via google maps. We love Mexican food so we definitely wanted to try this place out. 

It's a cute small little restaurant with a nice chill vibe. Really good food! 
Definitely recommend!

3.5 Stars. Make your own Guac is awesome! I've never had a bad combo. The Guac is always nice and chunky!
Huarache De Hongos- Flatbreads are flavorful, but a bit greasy.
Brisket and Fish tacos are my favorite.
Chicken taco is also pretty decent.
While the tacos look small, don't be fooled. They are overstuffed and delicious.
Mojitos and drinks are strong and tasty!
Service is always friendly in this low lit, cozy restaurant.

This is a review for restaurant week. The service was sub-par but the food was good enough to warrant a second visit to give Xochitl another try.

Our group was promptly seated by the host and quickly filled out the "build your own guacamole" card placed at our table. The host returned to our table a few minutes later and asked if our server had visited to take our drink order, she had not but it hadn't been that long so no big deal. He took our guacamole card and drink order, a few of us settled on El Pepinos (jalapeno infused tequila, simple syrup, lime juice and muddled basil) - yummy!

After the host returned with our drinks he asked to take our order as our waitress had yet to check on us - we had been seated for about 15 minutes by this point. Again, not annoyed because at least someone was waiting on us, right?! As always, I asked for recommendations and let's just say his reaction to this question was a little awkward, his "are you kidding me?!" expression and lack of recommendations ("everything is good") was off-putting. Moving on...

We ordered the flatbread and empanadas for appetizers and the braised short ribs and steak for entrees. The flatbread was a little chewy, maybe because the "crust" was maza - which is fine, but I think it was made too far in advance as a function of restaurant week so it seized up and became hard to chew. The mushrooms and cilantro toppings were good though. Some of my friends loved the three cheese empanadas, while I thought they were a little greasy - but hey, it's fried dough stuffed with cheese so I think it's a given that the dish is going to be a little greasy. The sauce and corn salsa served with the empanadas were really good though. 

The entrees were ok, not great, just OK. The flavor of both were great but the rice on the side of each plate was bland and the temperature of both dishes was luke warm at best. The desserts are not even worthy of the time it'd take me to type, but let me say this: the tres leche cake was such an odd consistentcy I am convinced it's not a cake but rather overcooked rice mushed into a cake form...yep.

My favorite go-to Mexican places will remain El Rey and Los Cabellitos...All that being said, I will give Xochitl another try because it was restaurant week and other places have been redeemed after an OK initial experience.

Smallest menu selection I've ever seen at a Mexican place.

Queso fundido was odd and pretty greasy.  Short rib tamale was flavorful but again oddly served.

Portions are tiny.  Pretty cheap if you don't drink.  We drank.  Mojitos were good but $10.

I would just recommend going somewhere else.  I think others would agree seeing as there was no one there on a Saturday night.

Very rarely do I go out for restaurant week and end up full!  Four decent sized courses.  The chicken was AMAZING.  I'm the boring person at each restaurant week table that orders the chicken dish, but I did not regret it at all.  It was so tasty and perfectly cooked.  The chocolate dessert was to die for.  The smoked salmon course was also very tasty.  The $10 coupon for a return trip is a good idea, and I will definitely be back.  The atmosphere is a lot of fun, and the service is friendly and paced correctly: not too quick where you feel like you are being thrown out, but not so slow that you end up starving.  The margarita was sizeable and yummy.  :)
Went here for the first time today, what an amazing gem! The staff, drinks, service and FOOD were all amazing.  Very clean facility and nice ambiance.  Will definitely be returning
Great.  Great.  Great.  The guacamole....design your own recipe.  The pepino margarita...addicting.  The street corn....don't leave without ordering it.  The tacos are pretty pricey but delicious.

I've been meaning to get back to Xochitl for awhile and here's why. I've only been there once for a price fix event and was so impressed that ever since I've wanted to go for a full menu tasting. They have great deals on food and drinks and they really are just a unique meal experience. Not to say that I eat in a boring fashion, but eating at Xochitl feels like a whole new way of eating to some extent. Their ceviches are delightful, their drinks to die for, and their staff are all ever so helpful at describing the menu, recommending things they enjoy, and making your meal enjoyable. I definitely need to go back again- and you, you should go too!

So I went for the Sabores Ingidenas night. This was the celebration of pre-hispanic Mexico. My guest and I arrived early and sat down for some happy hour discount margaritas that kicked butt. The bartender had been given some of the roasted grasshoppers that would be in the grasshopper taco entree and he passed these along to us. They were great, with a dusting of chipotle powder that made them taste like slightly spicy popcorn. I'd eat these any day over the crap some bars put out as a snack. 

We had made reservations for 5pm the first day this menu was being offered, which just happened to correspond with St. Patrick's day, so the crowd was light. We ordered the special menu with the beverage accompaniment. 

For appetizers we had the grasshopper tacos and the zucchini blossoms with air-cured beef. I know - shame on me for not getting the breaded veal brains, but my stomach was a bit off from a cold earlier in the week and I was concerned something that unique to my palate might result in a scene. 

The tacos were delish, and the grasshoppers really didn't add more than a crunchiness to the taco. The air cured beef was also nice, resembling a light speck in taste. The accompanying beverage, was rum infused with honey and anise, and was wayyyyyy to sweet for me. I passed this to my guest, who enjoys sweeter drinks and gave it thumbs up. 

Second course brought venison meatballs with huitlacoche sauce and tostadas with monkfish tinga. The meatballs were quite heavy, and I wished for more of the huitlacoche in the sauce as the taste was very faint. The tostadas were nicely light with good portions of monkfish. The beverage was tequila with fermented pineapple and piloncillo. Nice and not too sweet. 

For the third course, we had the frog legs with butter and garlic and braised wild boar. Both dishes were perfectly prepared and tastes as expected. The frogs legs were light and sweet, and the boar rich and woodsy. Mezcal with prickly pear juice was the accompanying drink and my favorite of the lot. 

For dessert we ordered the tropical fruit flan and the chocolate cake with amaranth and walnuts. The flan was the winner here, with rich taste and a surprising lightness, and both my guest and I like chocolate, so it was a surprise to both of us we liked this over the chocolate cake. The cake was good, but the flan was great. The drink was agave, mango, and coconut and again was too sweet for me. My guest liked it, though noted the agave gave it a substantial viscosity. 

Overall - the food was very good and the experience of trying some of these fun, off the normal menu dishes was great. I wouldn't hesitate to go back to try the regular menu.

Last night, the cozy yet bustling ambiance of Xochitl really shone through for me. Maybe it was all the new people I met, or all the faces I hadn't seen in a while, or exchanging a game of footsie with my friend - whatever it was, Xochitl really came alive.

The experience began by sitting at the bar (often a wise decision) under the care of Eric. He's a pro and just before you've cleared your last sip, he's at the ready with a new drink in hand or a quick recommendation. Eric is fast and efficient without being unnecessarily chummy but don't let it fool you, you'll be exchanging high fives after your 3rd or 8th drink. He also happens to be one of the most respected bartenders in Philly. 

New chef Lucio Palazzo has maintained many of the old beloved dishes while adding some excellent new choices to create an accessibly smart menu. 

Some things you should check out:
-La Chilindrina (blanco tequila, blood orange, lime, canela, chile)
-Chespirito (poblano-infused blanco tequila, green chartreuse, St. Germain)
-Cazuela de chorizo y papas (caserole of chorizo, potatoes, and kale)
-Queso fundido

Regretfully, I did more drinking than I did eating, but the little I did have definitely piqued my interest for some more. Perfect spot for a date or a late night drink. Actually, it's just awesome all around.

What a wonderful experience this was! I really enjoyed Xochitl! We started off with a Chipotle Guacamole which was made at the table with fresh chips. My meal consisted of Sopa de Pollo Humeado (mexican chicken soup), followed by the Vuelva a la Vida (shrimp, octopus, scallops and oyster cocktail). What a meal!! It was topped off with a wonderful array of desserts. May favorite, the Churros! I am a huge fan of the affordably priced Xochitl!

I love this restaurant.  I went two weeks in row I liked it so well.

The drinks are great, the food is excellent, and the atmosphere is perfect.  Its a great place for couples or groups of friends.  Excellent tequila selection as well.

The owner is a very nice guy and owns Marigold's as well -- another excellent restaurant.  

Great place.

This is one of my favorite restaurants in old city! The tacos (especially the short rib) are absolutely delicious. It's not the cheapest restaurant, but you leave feeling full and satisfied! The service is great and the outside music is very enjoyable.

The ambiance of the restaurant is great! Right around society hill with spacious outdoor seating. 

For the price of the food, i expected a lot more. The portion sizes of the chicken tacos (3) was good, flavoring and texture were on point for the actual chicken but the tortilla themselves could've been used as a frisbees. They were rubbery, tough, and chewy. For $13 for 3 TACOS, I'd expect the whole meal in its entirety to be edible but the tortilla were so tough i just ate the chicken.

Also had the chorizo queso fundido- don't be fooled by the prettiness of it, the cheese was tough and rubbery, the chorizo itself dry and lacked flavor. It had some spice/kick but other than that eh. 

Overall for the cost of the meal and the flavors, i don't think I'll be coming back

I've been here a handful of times for dinner and always enjoyed my meal. They recently updated their interior and menu and I definitely enjoy the new menu options. On my most recent visit I ordered the tostadas de tinga for an appetizer and they were excellent. For an entree I had the Arachera: marinated skirt steak a la plancha, caramelized onions, tomatoes, salsa rancherapostres which was really good as well. I definitely suggest this place for an upscale Mexican option. 

Besides great food they also have some of the best margaritas I've ever had. They make them completely from scratch with fresh lime and no crappy Margarita mix. They have a great late night happy hour downstairs from 10pm-12am.
My boyfriend got food poisoning from eating here last night. NEVER AGAIN! How about practicing some basic cleasniness to the people who entrust you to prepare their food.

I just ate here last night for the first time ever.  All I can say is this was by far the BEST mexican food I have ever had!  It wasn't crowded which was awesome for us.  The atmosphere is really cozy, and the custom Guacamole was great! We'll definitely be coming back here!

My friend and I came to Xochitl when we were visiting Philly from NY. We had a reservation, but had about a 10 minute wait when we got there. We ordered a drink at the bar and when our table was ready we were able to transfer our bar bill to the table. Our server was really nice and gave some suggestions on appetizers. 
They have an option where you can create your own guac by checking off the ingredients you want in it on a card and giving it to the waiter. We went with pretty standard guac BUT we got it topped with cotija cheese, literally amazing. We were hesitant about getting the cotija on it, but it really was so good
For dinner we both got a few different tacos and split them. We tried the chicken, brisket, carnitas, short rib and shrimp soft tacos. They were really good, but the taco was soggy with some of them. 
All in all the food was good, and the staff was nice and helpful. I would return if I was ever in the area again.

For real, though, tequila is no longer just something to justify going home with ugly people anymore.  Xochitl, like its sister restaurant the magnificent Zahav, goes above and beyond the norm to create an amazing dining experience.  I always chill at the bar, as Xochitl has some of the most hospitable and knowledgeable (not to mention heavy-handed) tenders in the city.  

Though some truly great tequilas will set you back a bit its more than worth it.  Personally, I'm partial to the Casa Noble Anejo, a tree-bark brown delight that my friends and I describe as "the one that smells like Grandma and tastes like Grandpa."  A warm butterscotch nose precedes the cherry tobacco flavors, finished with lively spearmint.  Its on this one that I really learned to appreciate sipping tequila rather than the old standby: lick, slam suck.  No limes and salt, please, just a snifter-shaped glass and a side of sangrita (the amazing spicy tomato and citrus aperitif served alongside most tequilas enjoyed neat).

Its impossible to be steered wrong on the menu--everything is heavenly--but the true delight is always going to be the tequilas, whether standing by themselves, in one of the creative house cocktails or in the margarittas made with freshly squeezed limes.

As an added bonus, Xochitl is quite often a bustling hub of food industry peeps, especially on Sundays.  You're never going to find a more lively, and engaging crowd.  Staff from Zahav--those lucky bastards--are encouraged to enjoy their shift drink at Xochitl (and vice versa) but chances are you'll find restaurant people from all over the city.  And really, if there's one group you ought to trust about where to find the best food and drink, its them.

Great tequila selection and bartenders who know their stuff -- always a plus. Took a couple visits for me to make it past the bar to sit for dinner and was definitely glad that I did. The food was awesome...

Food is good enough to come if you're in the area and like a more American take on Mexican food. Waitstaff is good except for the main bartender, who is a little aloof. A little expensive. Good margaritas.

This place was pretty good. The bar had plenty of tequila and margarita options, and several goid beer and wine options. The service from our hostess, to the bartenders and our waitress, was outstanding. Friendly, thoughtful, and just on "it." We ordered the make your own guac (red onions, roasted garlic, jalepenos, black truffle and cilantro), the huaracho (sp?) with chorizo, the El Dorado (pan seared salmon, stuffed with lump crab, over a jalepeno cream corn and a small arugula salad) and the spicy brisket enchiladas. Everything was delicious. My salmon was slightly overdone (reason for 4 stars) but still extremely tasty. The ambience was perfect. My only big complaint was with the couple next to us talking about fecal matter next to us during dinner...but that's not on the restaurant. Defintely want to try the rest of the menu and make this place a part of our rotation.

It can be hard to find a venue large enough to seat 16 at one table, and that is one of the advantages to coming here.  The food itself was just okay, although we did like the make-your-own guacamole option.  If you do decide to add truffle, be aware that it will overpower the rest of the flavors!  They were also out of the marinated fish tacos tonight, and while the spicy brisket tacos were decently spicy, they were also quite small and a bit bland.  The braised boneless short rib was tender and flavorful, and came topped with a savory blend of mushrooms, corn, and onion, all served over rice.  I would recommend this, as well as the baby back ribs, although I am sure that you can get comparable quality, or better, at Percy's.  The perk here is that they were spicy.  The shrimp chile nogada was solid with a good balance of shrimp, rice, queso, and surprising addition of pomegranate seeds, but not very spicy.  The version at El Rey is definitely spicier.   The short rib tamales were probably the least favorite, as they were small, dry, and bland, despite the generous side of chili gravy.  Service was decent, but overall, the food was pricey (~$25-30/entree and $16 for tacos) for the small portions and not as flavorful as Veracruzana.  The location is great, though, and it is a fun spot for a larger group.

We found this restaurant walking through this area as we were looking for a dinner spot. The restaurant wasn't very full but it was a Monday night so I imagine it's just not very busy because of that but at least we were seated pretty promptly. 

We were greeted and had our drink orders placed promptly. Since the restaurant was running a "meatless Mondays" special, all non-pork/chicken/beef items were 15% off. I decided to have the shrimp tacos, an order of the fried yucca and a margarita. The table also decided on guacamole to share. The guacamole is "made to order" by using the card on the table to pick your ingredients. There are definitely some non-traditional ingredients on their like strawberries, pomegranates, and some other things. We decided to stay in the traditional lane of ingredients and we enjoyed appetizer and our waiter brought a second round of chips without being prompted which was nice.

My favorite bite of the night was the yucca fries. They were perfectly prepared and served piping hot. I'm kind of a yucca fry snob so this was really exciting for me. The shrimp tacos were okay. The toppings looked fresh and colorful and the shrimp were large but the sauce on the taco didn't quite do it for me. Overall, it was a very wet taco and the flavors of what was in it just didn't have enough dynamics in flavor and texture. Was it tasty? Sure. Would I order it again? Unfortunately, no.

Overall, I would say that if you eat at this restaurant knowing it's a fusion Mexican restaurant, it's perfectly fine. If you go in expecting more traditional flavors then you might be disappointed. I was in between three and four stars for my rating but decided on four since the waiter, Ian, was really attentive and kind and brought us a flan at the end of the meal. Also, the bartender came and asked if we wanted to see anything on TV and changed the channels so we could watch the Sixers game. In addition, the restaurant had a nice romantic mood (though some might find it dark). All pluses that bumped up their overall rating. Personally, I prefer a traditional Mexican meal over fusion but I think the food was tasty regardless.

We went on New Years Eve (2020) and had a great time! Service was super friendly and attentive. They have seating in the covered walkway with heaters. We were all warm enough. 

The food was really good. We started with salsa and guacamole and the salsas were so yummy and authentic. 

We all got shrimp tacos. The shrimp could have been slightly less breaded but overall the flavor was really good.

I went here for the first time last week and it was very good. I had a spicy margarita, chicken tacos, and guacamole. The service was great and everything came out pretty quickly.

The happy hour menu looks good, so maybe I'll try that next time.

I do think it is a bit overpriced compared to other Mexican restaurants in Center City.

Visited this place after hearing about the Sunday night $35 special and went there fully intending to take advantage.  However, once we got there we realized that whatever sparked our interest on the menu wouldn't add up to $35/person so we skipped it and ordered ala carte.  For starters the guacamole made tableside was well worth the $8 - what a treat!  Too bad it was in a lava bowl or we would have licked it clean.  Dinner was good (he had the pork and I had the Enfrijoladas) but not amazing - the Enfrijoladas were lacking ... something.  If this was the kind of place that had hot sauce on the table I definitely would have indulged.  Ended up having my share of the pork.  Service was great, extremely attentive but not pushy.

Very cool looking place in one of my favorite corners in Philly, Headhouse Sq. First thing to notice, is they obviously have a killer tequila list. I chose to sizipp on some Don Julio up, and they delivered it with some tomato/Tabasco palette cleanser thing that was essentially a spicy virgin bloody Mary. Wonderful tequila and a nice touch.

A drink is one thing, but the real deal is obviously the food. We started with the Vuelva a la Vida ceviche (scallop, squid, oyster, shrimp). It was pretty darn good, presented nicely with cilantro, onion, tomato, chile, and a tomato type sauce. Next up, I had the mixed grill, which was good, but nothing earth-shattering -- as my wife put it, "glorified fajitas". Again, not to say that it wasn't good, but really nothing great special for the price (most expensive on the menu). My wife had the enfrijoladas, which were disappointing tortilla wrapped veggies, with barely any veggies inside. Finished everything with the churros which as others mentioned, are radical.

We were both kind of underwhelmed, but I'd go back to visit Don Julio again.
Horrible place. Took 1.5 hours to get our food and when we asked if the food was ready waitress she gave us a snarky remark. I would not recommend coming here!

Ill  assume that I went on a bad night bc I was highly disappointed in this place. We went during Restaurant Week and that was our only options to choose from. All the courses were super  bland. The tortilla soup tasted like dish water and my chicken course as well as all of our entrees were so piled high with cilantro to compensate for the lack of flavoring  we barley finished our meals. If cilantro is the chefs idea of "authentic" mexican flavoring I would probably go back to the basics of plain old salt and pepper!. The desserts were equally disappointing. The server even told us to stay away from the flan!!  Service was good but Ive had much much better. We all left highly disappointed and I do not recommend this place during Restaurant Week.

Yum. It could be the fact that my wife and I were both freaking starving, but we annihilated this food. It was delicious. 

Guacamole to start. We were able to tailor it to our liking since it was made tableside (extra jalapeño and habanero for us). 

To start, we also got the tostadas de ceviche (mackerel) and the cazuela de chorizo y papas . Both were solid. Ceviche was prepared with the perfect balance of lime, cilantro, onion, jalapeño, and tomato. Just so tasty. The cazuela was delicious as well--the kale complemented the chorizo very nicely. 

Entrees: I got the costillas de puerco, baby back ribs in a mole sauce served with pickled veggies and refried beans. She got the arroz con pollo frito, which was two pieces of chicken battered in a tortilla chip crust served over rice and veggies with two sauces. Like KFC with less of a hit on your self esteem after finishing it. Both dishes were awesome. Healthy portions which is always nice. 

Cocktail menu had a nice selection of unique tequila niceties. We had four of them, three of which were awesome.

Overall, it's not street tacos, but it's pretty freakin good Mexican food.

During covid they have outdoor separated seating- when we asked for a table for 4 they brought the table from inside to outside so we can be seated. Servers all wearing masks.

For veggie option the veggie tacos were just okay but nice they have the non-meat option! Signature guacamole was an interesting starter- some sweet fruits but ultimately full of heat from the habanero

Margaritas were the best part! Recommend the blood orange margarita!

Not a place I could come back to twice

I bought a livingsocial voucher for a 4 course dinner for 2 for $79 for this place and finally got the chance to give it a try last night. I made a reservation on opentable and was excited because it was a 1000 point time, which is awesome! When we arrived our waiter seated us and handed us menus and explained the create your own guacamole thing they have. I told him we had a livingsocial voucher, he stopped in his tracks and ran off to go find the prix fixe menus. He didn't return. He was replaced with another waiter (possibly the manager?) who explained that our opentable reservation had to be canceled because we couldn't have a voucher and receive points for our reservation. It doesn't say that anywhere on the voucher or on opentable that I can find, but ok. 

We each ordered a margarita one perfect and one rosa for $13 each. They were both really tasty, but after you got through all the ice, it was about 2 oz of liquid. Definitely not worth the $13. The guacamole was good and so was the mushroom flatbread. The ceviche was nothing special. It was bland aside from the peppers and needed more citrus. The entrees we got were the fried chicken and the short rib. The chicken and the cornbread it came with were really good, but the salad that came with it was so spicy that neither of us could eat it. I love spicy food, but this was just not worth fighting through the pain. The short rib was a little dry, but the sides that came with it (rice and a pepper and onion stir fry) and the sauce it was in was very good. The deserts were not good. We got the flan and the chocolate cake. Both were a weird texture, the flan was more thick and gelatinous than I've ever had flan and the chocolate cake was a wet mush that looked like ground beef with whipped cream on top. 

When we received our check, our waiter informed us of what the price of the meal would have been without the voucher and what the actual price was. I buy groupons and vouchers often and I'm always sure to tip on the actual amount, not what I paid for the voucher, so I was put off by having it pointed out as if to say this is what you should tip me on. If I need to know what the actual cost of the dinner was, I will ask you. 

I won't coming back here. The service was rude and the prices were way to high for what this restaurant is. If I want pricey Mexican I'll go to El Vez and get a decently portioned margarita for $13.

Came here tonight for restaurant week and to celebrate 6 months of marriage. It was the perfect spot and ambience! I have been here before for happy hour and thoroughly enjoyed the offerings then. Tonight's food surpassed my previous experience. 

The guacamole was truly the star of the dinner. They allow you to customize your guacamole so we added red onion, roasted tomatoes, and chipotle. The ratio of guacamole to chips was perfect--neither was left in excess. I mentioned to my husband that if I could replace another course with an additional guacamole course I would do it. 

I ordered the posole soup for the second course and the spice level was just right, with tender pieces of meat. My husband had the ceviche and enjoyed it as well.

For the third course I ordered the seafood enchiladas and they came with a side salad. It was light and creamy and delicious. My husband said he would order it again despite not being an enchilada fan generally. He said the difference was the cream-based sauce as opposed to the usual salsa verde sauce. 

Finally, we ordered one of each of the two dessert options. The flan was light and had a lovely texture and mouth feel. The tres leches cake was rich and sweet. The latter filled us right up, but they were both perfect with the coffee served in a French press. The coffee was extra, but it was a lovely complement. 

Thank you for the wonderful night, Xochitle!

So many things were great about Xochitl. Ambiance is super cool and cozy, location can't be beat, drinks are on point. Everything was great except the lack of flavor in almost everything I tasted. 
The signature guacamole in theory was awesome. It features unique ingredients like pineapple, pomegranate seeds, etc. Yet managed to be completely void of flavor. My boyfriend thought it was hummus. I don't understand how this had no taste unless they don't use fresh ingredients. I don't understand. 
My favorite thing I tried was queso fundido with chorizo. That was on point and I loved how it was served with tortillas. 
For dinner I got a chicken tinga burrito which again had very little flavor. It was just completely uninspired. In my estimation mexican food should be super flavorful but this was not the case at all. 
We tried the churros for dessert and they were the only churros I've ever tried that didn't have cinnamon or sugar on them. Just greasy dough. Which isn't terrible but wasn't what I was expecting. 
I would come here again and just get drinks because their drinks were great. I sampled the blood orange margaritas and Mexican hot chocolate both of which were great. While the food here doesn't do it for me there's enough redeeming qualities to possibly bring me back for a drink.

This is a great hidden gem for happy hour. $3 beers, $6 margs, and $5 bar bites. Best part is the HH is mon-sun. Beers on tap were: dos Equis amber/lager, negro modelo, and corona light. I got the mini quesadilla for the bar bite and it was delicious yet filling. There is only a single bathroom in the back which is very tight quarters. Also, still not sure how to pronounce the name of this place. Overall - good food, affordable drinks, great location on 2nd and Pine next to a ton of other places. Will definitely be going back.

Pretty darn expensive place to eat, but the food was really good! Unfortunately, they dont even give salsa w the complimentary tortilla chips. But for the dish however (seafood enchiladas) the food was very tasty, tortillas were great, and the service was good. Enhiladas and other food is shareable!

I went to Xochitl for restaurant week, so I wasn't able to take advantage of the full menu.  But I really did enjoy what I had.  I think the dish I liked the most was their ceviche (theirs has octopus, which I love!).  

I had the salmon for dinner.  I have to say, I really didn't like the spices they put on it.  I appreciated the spiciness of it, but the overall flavor bored me. I felt I could recreate the dish easily using some sort of generic McCormick brand spices at my own home.  However, everything else we ate was absolutely delicious!  So maybe you should just avoid eating the salmon, unless you like generic spices.  

Oh, dessert was great, too.  I had some sort of apple tart.  Yum!

The atmosphere was really beautiful, with vivid colors on the walls.  The staff was very friendly, too.  Overall, I had a great experience.  I'd love to go back!
Amazing pick your own guacamole and servers taste test everything before serving! Food is authentic.
Great experience! I highly recommend this restaurant. I love the ambiance (candles on each table), great service, awesome manager, excellent food, nice menu, and a 10/10 if you ask me!

Xochitl is one of my favorite places to go for a drink in Philly. I hope that doesn't change anytime soon. The margaritas are the best and I do believe they are a bit larger than they used to be. But several staff changes (including the chef) over the past year lead me to this review update. 

I'm going to shoot straight: this new version of Xochitl is overpriced. Not for the drinks, which I feel are worth their tag, but for the food, which is sadly not as good as it was in the past. Wanting to share a few small plates for dinner on Saturday night, we ordered a red snapper ceviche for $14. The fish was more like sashimi with some red onion and orange pieces thrown in. There was absolutely no citrus taste to the fish itself, which is a staple in ceviche. It really lacked any kind of taste other than the snapper, which could have used a little salt as well. 

Two types of tacos were better in show. The steak tacos were juicy and very flavorful, and the chicken tacos with a nice, healthy slice of avocado were great... with the exception of a small bone in one of mine. The accompanying sides of black beans were slightly warmer than room temp and not so great. 

These three plates plus two margaritas each came close to $100, including a generous tip (we received a couple new drinks on the house in exchange for our thoughts on them so we wanted to make sure our server Michelle was covered). Happy hour will probably be the way to go for me in the future, because I cannot live without those amazing margs. Sadly, the late night happy hour I used to love on Thursday nights is no longer, but I'll happily pull up a seat from 5-7 on weekdays.

Really great food, really great for our group (we had 8 people), but there was a bit of a blunder with our bill--the entire bill was put on one person's card rather than just $25. While we're pretty sure that'll work out okay, it wasn't the greatest way to end an otherwise great dining experience.

If you like margaritas and guac, then look no further than Xochilt. My girlfriend and I continue to come here for dates for two reasons: 1) the margaritas, 2) make your own guac. Every table has a sheet with a golf pencil where you can literally customize your own guac that they will make for you. There are also a lot of margaritas and they add more depending on the season. The staff could not be more friendly and accommodating, and the main courses are delicious as well. We've been here at least 8 times in two years and will continue to come every time we get a chance.

Goods:  Place was very cozy, decor great, along with the service.   The Margaritas were amazing and had some great summer drinks, summer drinks were very fresh.

Downside:  Pricey for small portions and fish tacos were so so.
We went here for Happy Hour on a weekday evening and sat outside. Our waitress was extremely friendly & provided quick service. Margaritas and appetizers were tasty!

If you want Mexican food, goto to Lolita.  I had the Tamal, Empanadas, and Parillada.  The food was not that great.  Also, we had to wait over 40 minutes for our food when the restaurant was not that crowded.

We had a late dinner here for a friend's birthday.  Since it was the first time for a lot of us, we all decided to go with the El Sabor ($23 for guacamole, appetizer, and taco) and dine family style.  Since there were 9 of us, you can guess we pretty much ordered one of everything.    

They brought several guacamole for the table with the special being my favorite.  It had a hint of heat with a pineapple flavor in the background.  For me, I had the cazuela de chorizo y papas (chorizo with potatoes) and the carrillada de cerdo (beer-braised pork cheeks).  Everything tasted so fresh and tasty until I hit my taco.  It was hard for me to enjoy this part of my meal as I was already so full at this point.  Too much guacamole for me.  So, I can't give a true opinion of my taco, but it seemed tasty from what I can remember. 

The service and atmosphere were great.  Although, I've heard that the service can be a little slow.  It was the right pace for me as I like to enjoy my experience, plus I was in good company.  I would definitely recommend this place to anyone.

If you haven't had brunch at Xochitl yet, get thee a reservation. It won't be long before Sunday's little secret gets out. 

I've now been for breakfast on two separate occasions, and on both visits, everything has gone beyond my expectations. Full disclosure: My second visit was comped because my boyfriend and I were invited to come in and sample the menu. But our first visit was on us, and we arrived on the very first Sunday they started offering the brunch menu.

Starting with the drinks, the coffee has an ever so slight cinnamon taste that really goes well with the bold flavors of the food. Mimosas are served cold and taste fresh-squeezed. Bloody Marias are a bold take on traditional BMs, served with tequila and a chili-salt rim. Waters are filled regularly without having to make requests. 

Xochitl's ceviche remains one of my favorite preparations in the city. So light, so flavorful, no matter what variation they are serving it is always delicious. Skip the usual guacamole and share this light starter instead.

On both visits the boy and I ordered the same exact thing. For him, huevos con chorizo: Two sunny-side eggs baked in a dish with kale, potatoes and loads of chorizo. Just as good as it sounds. For me, huevos revueltos: Eggs scrambled with thick-cut, almost pancetta-like bacon pieces and spicy peppers, topped with queso fresco and spicy salsa and served with corn tortillas. Every bit as good with egg whites substituted for whole eggs, which I requested on my second visit. 

We also tried the cornmeal and black bean pancakes, topped with fresh whipped cream, seasonal berries and the most delicious syrup I've ever had the pleasure of eating. These pancakes were nothing like any I've ever known before and yet they ranked among the very best. Highly recommended. 

The sun-lit room with happy music made me actually feel like I was on a mini-vacation. This is how brunch is supposed to be.

Xochitl is a cute more upscale Mexican restaurant where you have the ability to build your own guac! It's in a adorable area in old city with a ton of indoor and outdoor seating. To start we had to get the guac and added a few add-ons.  We wished there was more as the portion was tiny but it was very flavorful.  The homemade chips were nice and salty.  For dinner we got two orders of tacos and the yuca fries.  The tacos needed more seasoning but the carnitas tacos were our favorite. The yuca fries were our favorite dish! The spicy aioli sauce was incredible.   All in all, this restaurant has a good atmosphere in a great area of Philly but is overpriced for what you are getting.

Located in a cute federal-style house just off Head House Square, Xochitl is a cozy spot for a drink at their spacious bar. We stopped in on a chilly Saturday evening for some pre-dinner margaritas, and found this spot to be a very relaxing way to spend a quiet evening. Their Perfect Margarita is quite good, and rivals anything I've had in Texas.

So I came here with some friends for restaurant week. When first looking at the menu, I thought the plethora of options was great because everything sounded good. The guacamole was seriously amazing. We got the jalapeño one and it was really spicy, but if you like spicy it will be perfect for you. I recommend getting the black truffle in your guac. 

The Huarache de Hongos was okay to be honest. I wasn't a huge fan and I probably wouldn't order it again. For the main dish, I ordered the Angus Flat Iron Tampiquena. This was actually really really good. A few of my friends ordered the Xochitl Mole Pepper and weren't too satisfied. Finally, dessert is usually my favorite part. I was pretty disappointed with how the desserts came out. The Mexican Chocolate & Ancho Chile Tart was way to overwhelming with the amount of raspberries that was in it. I ordered the Mango Tres Leche Cake and it was okay but I wouldn't order it again. Maybe the flan would have been better. 

Overall the place is really cute. The staff was great and helpful. The manager kept coming to our table to ask if we needed anything and if everything was okay. The food was decent but I think its one of those places where you go once and that's about it.

Even though I have NO idea how to pronounce it, this place will be on my short list of place to eat! We wanted to get out of Fairmount for dinner, and wifey has bene craving Mexican food. This place takes Mexican to a whole new level. MOnday through Thursday, they have a dinner special Molcateje, for $28. it's for 2 people, but can easily feed 3. It's a large steaming bowl of griled chicken, braised short rib, carnitas, chorizo, nopales (cactus), grilled spring onion and Cotija. You get to pick red or green sauce, we had the red and it was AWESOME!! it also comes with house made tortillas, think make your own taco set up. WE also started with an order of the guacamle and added goat cheese, which was fantastic! We also opted for a side of the rice with cotija. The Molcateje was just sublime. All the meats were cooked to perfection, the veggies were cooked but still maintained some of the crispness adn the tortillas were exactly what they should be. I was blown away at how good this meal was. The service was also great. I just went with a beer, but wifey had a margarita that blew her socks off! All in all, VERY impressed by this place.

Should have read the reviews! Mediocre at best, but I'll start with the positive. Incredible outside dining in a beautiful location. And the margaritas are good. Unfortunately the food and service both need attention. Service was slow and inattentive. Not bad, but completely mediocre. Half the entrees arrived 15 minutes after the first half and only when asked. The food was the biggest disappointment however. They tout the guacamole and it was a tiny portion and bland. The chips were not fresh (perhaps the humidity). The vegetarian tacos had an off flavor and the shrimp tacos were just ok. Fried shrimp and cabbage. Basic. I recommend going for drinks and yucca fries (the only highlight).

My wife and I went to Xochitl on a Saturday night, and we met quite a busy crowd.  Our first impression was the hostess, who worked some kind of magic and got us a table among the crowd.  She informed us about the build-your-own guacamole card on our table, and we got right to making an amazing custom build.  (Don't turn your nose up at the crab meat!  It's delicious!)

Our waiter, Mike, promptly came over to talk about the specials and briefly went over the menu.  We got the Red Snapper Ceviche, at his suggestion, for an appetizer.  It was perfect with the plantain chips that they paired it with.  My wife ordered the Salmon and I ordered the Camarones con Caldo.  She was quite pleased with the dish and I had to admit that the vegetables that came with it were enough to make a meal out of, hearty and perfect for a winter meal.  My dish was slightly spicy and came with an avocado salad that helped cool down the spice on the shrimp.  Delicious!

A word about their drinks....amazing.  The Perfect Margarita that the waiter suggested was strong and tasty.  He informed us that they didn't use mixes, and everything was fresh squeezed per drink.

I must say, Mike was extremely knowledgeable about the dishes and made a point to visit our table several times during our visit, even though it was a VERY busy night.  My water glass was never empty.  He even spent a little time chatting with us about our evening, seeming to be genuinely interested in how we were spending the rest of it.  Quite pleasant and he made us feel comfortable and at home among the crowd.

We will definitely be back, this time with friends!

I want to start out this review by saying that the tacos were amazing. We unfortunately had a very bad server. We were seated outside. Two males and one female. We had all taken trains into the city and we're having a fun day out. The waitresses served myself and the other male but for some reason refused to serve the female. When I said that my friend would like a drink the waitresses asked us where we came from. I told her we had just come from spruce street harbor park. The waitress and her attitude were condescending and not at all appropriate and she should be fired. My friend was extremely upset and outraged and walked away from the outdoor table we were seated at. Thankfully a manager or someone claiming to be management came and I explained the situation and told him I was willing to pay for the amazing tacos but they would have to take the alcohol off the bill because our night was now ruined. My friend was extremely upset and it troubled her for the remainder of the night. The waitress had no right to be that condesending to my friend. We were not rude, obnoxious or belligerent. We did indeed start being rude once the waitress made the comment asking us where we came from and would not serve my friend. I ate the remaining tacos while my friend felt embarrassed and cried. I paid for the tacos and left a zero tip. In all honesty now reflecting on the situation and how upset it made my friend for the remainder of the night I would like my full money back. I did not know when I paid for the tacos how much this situation would ruin the night. I felt we were incorrectly treated like children. I am a CPA, the other male a Ph.d and the female has a masters in economics and financial planning. We are all in our Thirities. It was truly amazing how much we were disrespected.

Thanks You.

My husband and I popped in here after a dance lesson at Society Hill Dance Academy across the way for an early evening refreshment, we grabbed a seat at the dark wooden bar. 
CHICHARRONES!!  Three words= Crackling, pork, rinds!! Sounds horrific, but let me tell you- if you ever thought about, intrigued to try them, THIS is the place to do it. They are accompanied with a radish, mint salsa verde and it's complete unhealth yumminess on your lips, but totally worth it! Wash it down with a margarita or shake it up with some tequila flights!! The guacamole was also delicious and compliments any drink on the menu.

I can't speak to the rest of the menu, but the tasty tidbits that we did have were muy delicioso:)

I have finally experienced the awesomeness that is Xochitl.  Reluctantly, after several seasons of passing up on Restaurant Week, I decided to give the promotion another shot.  Xochitl has made me a believer again.  My friend and I arrived slightly early for our 7 p.m. resie but we were escorted to a table immediately.  Our water glasses were filled and bread was dropped off with two buttery spreads.

Our server, whose name escapes me, was wonderful throughout the experience.  When she asked to take our drink order and I handed over the recipe for a "Skinnygirl Margarita," she didn't bat an eye although she did let me know that their regular margaritas are made only with tequila, fresh lime juice and a little bit of simple syrup.  No sour mix, no triple sec, no hidden agendas; just honest ingredients, served over ice, with a rim of salt.  I ended up taking her word for it.  (For the record, one Skinnygirl plus two positively delicious Xochitl margs equals three sheets to the wind, minus any trace of a stomachache, which I almost always get when I drink margaritas anywhere else.  Hallelujah!)  

The food was glorious.  For our first course, we both chose the tortilla soup.  Large bowls containing cubes of cheese, slices of avocado, tortilla strips and dried peppers were presented to both of us.  The broth was poured on top, tableside.  I really enjoyed this dish, although my friend and I agreed that the dried peppers had a curious taste.  She didn't like them, I was intrigued by them.  Next, we both ordered the octopus, mackerel and shrimp ceviche trio.  Each was served atop a little fried tortilla round.  I have been daydreaming about the octopus ceviche since I awoke this morning.  It was easily the most tender, well flavored octopus I have had (sorry, Mr. Garces).

For my entrée, I chose the squid hot pot, which was another win.  When the lid was removed from the pot, tender rings of squid in a spicy tomato sauce appeared before us.  I have to say, the dramatic presentations really made the dining experience special.  The woman seated next to me ordered a stuffed pepper that was so beautiful it could have easily been pictured in a food magazine.  Meanwhile, at our table, my friend had food envy as she was experiencing mixed feelings about her skirt steak (which I thought was good, although it was served lukewarm).  

For dessert, my friend had the churros, which came with three dipping sauces.  One of my favorite things in life is the right to choose several condiments to go with a meal and this presentation was right up my alley.  Fortunately, I had my own dessert to tackle; an appropriately sized mini chocolate soufflé with a mini scoop of cajeta ice cream alongside.  Perfection.

Our experience last night wasn't just great by Restaurant Week standards; it was great by any night's standards.  What a truly fantastic meal.  When our bill was dropped, along with a plate of mini biscotti (delish, by the way), we were also each given a $10 card to use any time before November 31.  My dining companion and I are already discussing what we will order on our return visit!

Just had dinner here on a quiet Tuesday night. I am sorry to say, it was majorly underwhelming. We waited well over an hour for entrées which arrived cold, greasy, and the tacos fell apart -- they were dry and  soggy at the same time. There were apologies from the waitress and from the chef who was also delivering the food to the tables. Clearly understaffed, and I feel badly for them but still, it was terrible! I'm hoping for them this was just an off night, but I will not be returning.

Cool spot but I wouldn't go back here unless it's for happy hour. Why? It's a little overpriced for average Mexican food. I guess that's what you get for trying to make Mexican food fancy?
I tried the mole, chicken enchiladas, brisket tacos, wings, guacamole and the salmon. 
All were delicious! I especially liked how it's a build your own guac. 

The margaritas were delicious, but again, it's hard for me to pay $10-$13 for a cup when I can get a pitcher during happy hour.

One of the best places I've been for Restaurant Week.  Here's what I had:

Ceviche trio: Tasty with strong flavors.  Loved the dipping sauces.
Smoked cinnamon figs w/ blue cheese: Yum!  Loved the combo of sweet cinnamon with pungent cheese.
Squid hot pot: Delicious.  Tender (not chewy) squid, and lots of it.
Churros w/ dipping sauces: Mmm.  Creme sauce was my fav, though you can never go wrong with dark chocolate.

Downstairs seating area was roomy and quiet.  Friendly, helpful service, and the cookies that came with the bill were an unexpected treat.  I love when I think I'm finished eating and out comes more food!  The $10 coupon for a return visit is a smart business plan... it encourages ppl to come back, and they'll certainly spend more than $10 when they do.

Definitely worth my $35 and Wed. night!

If you haven't had happy hour at Xochitl yet, you are missing out. From 5-7, get $3 drafts and $5 margs (the best in Philly, in my opinion). Late night Thursdays add half off to the bar menu. I suggest the guacamole, queso fundido, torta sliders, calamar, tacos de suadero and ceviche.

So basically, everything is awesome.

3.5 stars.
Great location, very good selection on wines and margaritas.
Overall, the food lacked a bit of punch for my taste and was a bit on the sweet side.
The signature guacamole, the shrimp tacos and the short ribs were all ok, but not memorable. 
Nevertheless the location is great and the personal amazing.
Go there for a drink and to relax!

Let me start by suggesting the Sunday evening deal. 4 courses for $30 bucks of this caliber food goes a long way right now.

The food I've had here the many times I've stopped in has been great. The guacamole is some of the best I've ever had and they make a ceviche, the Return to Life,  that in my heart stands above any other I've had in Philly. For both dishes all of their ingredients seem fresh and vibrant. 

Their entrees are often very adventurous (the indigenous menu  they just did was wild) and almost always hit the spot. 

Bartenders are all great...flights of tequila are interesting and you can learn a ton about the drink here. Beers aren't plentiful, but they have enough quality non-macros to be passable. 

My experience with the staff has always been exceptional. As I said, the bar tenders are friendly and interesting. The hostess I've had is always accommodating and organized given the size of the dining room. And the waitresses were always knowledgeable. 

Great place! Give it a try.

Was excited to try this cause the location was adorable! Was not really impressed with the quality of food or the service though, the waiter denied our drink order because we were with our sister (?) confused by this, they didn't really provide too much of an explanation. Their service was also sub par, the waiter never gave napkins or refilled our water. The tacos taste good but not overwhelmingly amazing, not sure if I'll be coming back but good luck!

I'm soooo happy that I stumbled upon this gem! I visited Xochital on Cinco de Mayo after a few failed attempts of grabbing last minute tacos from other nearby restaurants. As you could imagine, finding a wait time or making any type of reservation anywhere the day of was nearly impossible. Xochital was very accommodating and I was able to be seated with no wait time. 

I was seated in their downstairs area, which reminded me of a speakeasy and was very intimate. I ordered the guacamole, which was hands down the best Guacamole I've had in Philly!  When you order the Guacamole, you have the chance to customize the ingredients to your liking, which was a HUGE plus for me!  Along with the Guacamole, I had their spicy margarita and shrimp tacos. The spicy margarita is a must for those who like their marg with smokey hints. And the shrimp tacos topped off the meal! Overall, this was definitely one of my best experiences with Mexican cuisine in Philadelphia. I'm still dreaming of the Guac and will definitely visit again soon!

This is such a cute spot! I would highly recommend. They have a delicious guacamole, which is one of the main reasons you should visit. 

If you are a taco fan, please try their crispy shrimp tacos or their fish tacos. Divine! 

Ambience is great. Service was friendly. Definitely check it out!

Xochitl is a more traditional Mexican restaurant with some modern interpretations of classic dishes.  it's a small place, FYI.  Overall, I was underwhelmed, and expected a bit more.  The food was certainly not bad, but I found it a bit uninspired, the flavors only mediocre, and the service a bit lacking.  The portions seem small for the price, but the drinks are very good.  

I give it three stars because it's not a place I'd avoid, but certainly not one I'd choose to return.  I don't think you'd have a bad experience here, and if you're a Mexican food junkie, it's worth a try, just don't have too high an expectation and you'll either be happily surprised, or get exactly what you anticipated.

Came here for the margaritas after reading many of the rave reviews but was extremely disappointed! 

When I saw the Prickly pear margarita on the menu, I got so excited! I have been craving for one since I had it in San Antonio a couple years back and never saw it on any menu elsewhere.. As soon as I took a sip, I knew something was wrong. Bland - not sweet and tangy like it is supposed to be but just bland. Still, I wanted to give them the benefit of the doubt so I tried the Guava margarita but it was just as horrible. 

Sorry guys but 2 stars only for the guac and chips. And I simply don't understand how someone can say Xochitl serves the "best" margaritas - that's a lie!
